lg.l: AS Cowards would the Name of Cowards shun,
With Blustring Words, all said, and nothing done,
So Bully Poet I have known to scape
Such a hard Censure, would a Hero Ape,
And Paint Almanzor in a Monsters Shape.
Our Poet too, by such a Trick drawn in,
Too late repents the Self-deceiving sin:
For he forsooth,
In this ripe Age, where every Man's a Wit:
Lest he should be the only Blot was hit,
To save his Credit, as he thought, has writ,
Supposing that malicious Men might say,
Pox on't, he's Dull— he Dull— and writ a Play;
Why, I writ one, you know, but t'other day.
But, since the Folly did so far deceive him,
Faith, he's asham'd to ask you to forgive him:
For here he swears, if you look out for Wit,
You may as reasonably expect to meet
Wit or good Manners in a dull Lampoon,
Or Christian Quarter from a French Dragoon.
Humility in Prelates, Truth in Priests,
Or in an Irish Coffee-house good Jests.
(Where, with our fancy'd Ruins, they make merry,
And from Mouths charg'd with smoak, Bomb London-Derry.)
No, Faith, our Author Imitates Ragoo,
For as without a shirt he was a Beau;
So without Wit he sets up for a Poet,
And thinks himself no more oblig'd to show it.
For if like Bays, all Poets should take pains
In letting Blood, and Physicking their Brains,
The Doctors Bill would sweep the third days gains.
Sure then, 'twas more Judicious Bays design'd,
Than Purging of his Body; ay, 'twas his mind,
To temper it to bear with every Wind.
Thus to the change of Times, he changes Rhimes,
Whilst to the face of things his fancy Chimes,
And moulds his Soul and Body with the Times.

div.head: THE FORTUNE-HUNTERS: OR, Two Fools well met.
SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter at two several Doors, two Wealthys, Brothers.

sp.speaker: Elder Brother.
sp.p: WHat Frank alive! mad Frank alive!

sp.speaker: Young. Brother.
sp.p: Even so, sober Tom, and glad to see you here in Town, which cannot have been long: Pray when?

sp.speaker: Elder.
sp.p: Not yet a full week: But Frank, I shou'd chide thee; for tho thou'rt a Rakehelly Non-resident fellow to any particular place, our Father old Sir William's House stands where it did; and a slight direction wou'd have secur'd a Letter to your Loving Brother. Tho the old man has forsaken thee, I never did Frank.

sp.speaker: Young.
sp.p: Brother, I never write, 'tis my aversion: A man that writes must think and be serious, which I never was, nor never will be. Talk as much as you will, but Writing's my Abomination.

sp.speaker: Elder.
sp.p: Why Frank, 'tis the only way of Conversation with absent Friends.

sp.speaker: Young.
sp.p: Ay, but there's great charge in Paper, and one Letter begets another; besides the expence of saying fine things. And then end with a damn'd Hypocritical Conclusion, of your Faithful Friend and Servant, to a Rogue it may be you wish hang'd.

sp.speaker: Elder.
sp.p:
Well, I find thou keep'st thy humour still, never to constrain
thy self to please thy friends. But why have you not ask'd how my Father does? What brought us to Town, or where you might see us?

sp.speaker: Young.
sp.p: Why first, I suppos'd he was well, or dead or alive, there's nothing to be got by him. Next, I suppose you came to Town for the same reason I stay in Town, to Whore and Drink. Lastly, I thought I might meet you in a Bawdy-house.

sp.speaker: Elder.
sp.p: Well judg'd, dear Frank, but I'll inform you better; my Father is well, and we came to Town upon the Condition of a match between the Beautiful Daughter of my Lord Lovewit deceased, and your then happy Brother Tom Wealthy.

sp.speaker: Young.
sp.p: Joy, Sir.

sp.speaker: Elder.
sp.p: Abate a little, Sir; for tho the Lady's Consent and Inclination intitle me the man, even since we came to Town, in that short time, a brace of Fops at Covent-Garden Church, have so far insinuated themselves, upon a slight acquaintance with my Father, that every hour almost in every day they are paying their Devoirs. I'll not disturb my Soul so far to think I am wrong'd, but one, and to my face, she so far favours, as wou'd provoke a man of a less Jealous temper than my self: If this be the effects of going to Church, they Church it by themselves for her or Tom.

sp.speaker: Young.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Tom, rail not against the Church, but down on thy knees, and thank Heav'n thou brought'st her safe off: Why man, they are the very Heart-hunters in Christendom: if thy Lady be not proof against Eye-shot and Ear-shot, thou'rt undone: Such nice surprizes, at so sweet a Face, such amorous glances of half Zeal half Love, such cocking of Cravat-strings and of Noses, with Perriwiggs so exquisitely set, that happy is the Woman looks and lives.

sp.speaker: Elder.
sp.p: This is terrible News for a poor Country Gentleman: but I'll dispatch my Marriage instantly, or cut the Throat of him that hinders it. And Frank, she has a Cousin worth 10000 l. And faith, thou'rt a young fellow Worthy, wou'dst thou but leave these Courses—

sp.speaker: Young.
sp.p: Thus speaks the Elder Brother. Leave these Courses! Pox Course you; what wou'dst thou have me do? You have the Estate, and yet I wear as good Cloaths as you do; Eat and Drink as well as you do; keep as good Company as you do; and you'll allow I'm the better Gentleman, by being the Younger Brother. Well, prethee tell me where you lodge, for I'm resolv'd to make a visit to my Father, not forgetting this 10000 l. you speak of.

sp.speaker: Elder.
sp.p: Why, at this very House.

sp.speaker: Young.
sp.p: What, the Widdow Sly's?

sp.speaker: Elder.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Young.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, my Widdow! I had a Note from her but just now, which was not unwelcome; for I had damn'd ill luck at the Groom-Porters last night. Well, my Duty to my Father, and tell him I must pay him a visit; I have some small acquaintance with the Widdow, and I shall gain Admittance.

sp.speaker: Elder.
sp.p: By the way, Frank, I doubt you have a Rival of the old Gentleman: But more of that when I see you next; I'll find that out. You are in haste, and I a truant to my Mistress. Adieu: Don't fail Frank, for she is so much of thy temper, I dare almost promise thee success. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well Cousin, this London's a delicate place; oh foh upon Sir William's old nasty House in the Country: If e're you catch me there agen! I did pennance enough in my Dads days: I'll no more of your Baing, Cackling and Crowing in a morning; if I must be wak'd out of my sleep, it shall be with the dear Rattling of Coaches, that, if I look out, I may see some gay thing fit to divert my eyes; without that eternal prospect of Beasts, and bare Fields.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Thou art a mad Girl, and this mad fancy will soon be cloy'd; but if you are resolv'd to stay after our return to the Country, with what Reputation will you live here, a single young Woman expos'd to the malice of this Rascally Town.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Not so fast good Cousin: A single young Woman may be otherwise if she please; and I am under no Vows that I know, unless this now; That the first young Gentleman that I like, (if he has good manners enough to like me) shall have the spending of this ten thousand pounds of mine, rather than I'll dye of the Pip, to leave it to you and your Heirs.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Well then, if you are upon choice, what think you of the two fine dress'd Gentlemen we came acquainted with at Church. There's danger indeed in looking on them.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Oh foh! filthy old Effeminate Fools. Danger in them? none on my Conscience, I dare swear it, if they were to be try'd; though
indeed, my dear Cousen, I observ'd you a little over civil to Mr. Shamtown, who receiv'd it with all the good manners in the World.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Well Girl, since you are resolv'd to Marry, I'll give you some advice; this Gentleman, this Mr. Wealthy, is the man on Earth, bait but his sin of Jealousie I'd choose, which I am resolv'd to cure (if possible) e're I resign my self to what I wish: For after that Maria, the Salique Law's in force against us all, and then adieu to Government for ever: Our frowns no more can kill, nor smiles revive: The humblest Lover makes a Lordlike Husband.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I apprehend you, then you mean to write the folly of his Jealousie so plain, in the two faces of these Amorous fools, that he may Read it there.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Right Girl, but you must joyn in this great Plot; for sure you must discern what Love and Languishment my Lovers friend exprest to you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: To me! upon my life he hardly ever spoke, and then so softly, I cou'd hardly hear; he lookt indeed and sight, and set his Cravat-string, and sight agen, and Comb'd his Perriwig: sight a third time, and then took snuff, I guess to show the whiteness of his Hand. And all the speech he made to all this Action, was, Renounce me, Madam, but you are very handsome; expecting, I suppose, the same return.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Well, this is making Love, the very newest way of making Love, and yet that Wealthy can so slightly weigh my Judgment, or my Love; to think me fond of such a nauseous Fop; but I'll Revenge my self this very way; I'll point my whole discourse to him, like every thing he does, praise him to Wealthy's face, and ask his Judgment of him; and as I find the ill-natur'd Fit work in him, I'll treat my new acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And I must sigh, I judge too with my Lover: Well, I do hate a sneaking, whining, crying, lying, dying Fellow, of all things in Nature: Give me the airy, sprightly free Gallant, such a one as they report young Wealthy to be. I long to see him, but this old Sir William will not suffer him, they say, to come into the House; yet as ill-natur'd as he is to his own flesh, he has a great inclination for mine, for he can hardly ever keep his hands from my bosome. And what way shou'd he take to make love to me, but by railing at youth, especially his Son Frank, who shall starve he says, e're he get a Groat from him.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p:
And you may believe him, for he's the gripingst old Jew living: Frank too made bold with five hundred pounds of his, which he can
never forgive. But see here comes my Lord and Master. Ah Tom, wou'dst thou but quit that Jealous humour, tho 'tis bred of Love, 'tis nurs'd by Folly; Love, Honour and Obey, shou'd be my Song for ever.

sp.speaker: Weal.
sp.p: Ladies, good day to you; what, not for Church this morning, Ladies? Methinks, tho your Zeal may be somewhat allay'd, so much good Company as meet there might invite you to Prayers.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: O, goes it there? teaze him Cousen.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Wealthy, I'll swear you are in the Right, there is the finest Company, the finest Ladies, and the finest Gentlemen! 'twou'd do a bodies heart good to look upon them. Upon my life they spoil'd all my Devotion; 'twas well for you, my Cousen made her choice before she saw these fine things, had you been in Love with me you had been undone.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: You speak but your own Opinion on that Maria, though truly Mr. Shamtown, and Mr. Littlegad, are the civilest, best bred men I ever saw; especially Mr. Shamtown, he is the pleasantest Creature, so good humour'd, and so Witty, he is three in Company at any time.

sp.speaker: Weal.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, I will allow him a fine Person, and a pleasant Creature, and three in Company; but for Wit, indeed Madam, 'tis much more your goodness than his desert.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, I won't answer for Mr. Shamtown, but I'll swear Mr. Littlegad has Wit, and more than that he is in Love with me.

sp.speaker: Weal.
sp.p: I doubt not that Madam; but has he told you so?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, but he has sigh't, and that's all one; besides he set his Perriwig and Cravat-string, for fear I shou'd not like them. Pho, I know he is in Love with me, and for ought I know, I am in Love with him too.

sp.speaker: Weal.
sp.p: Very fortunate fellows these, a poor Country Lover shall ride you twenty miles a day, only to play a Game at Lantrelew, and go every Night home in the dirt and the dark, and shall hardly be believ'd to be in Love, though he break a Limb by the way; whilst one of these pleasant Creatures, by a new fancy'd Dress, or nice ty'd Knot, shall conquer a young Lady in a trice.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: But then you must consider Invention is the labour of the brain, and exceeds that of the body.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And what signifies your Country Fools twenty mile a day to please his Mistress, when one of these shall sit you twenty hours together, almost distracting his dear Head, to find new fashions out, to delight us Ladies.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: And should not we be grateful, Mr. Wealthy, to these, who as if they were of a Religious Order, abandoning and renouncing all your lewd Debaucheries of Wine, wholly devote themselves to us, and our diversion.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Present his Duty to me, wait upon me, he's a Bastard, no Son of mine, and if he comes here I'll send him to Newgate, a Rogue!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, good Sir William, who has offended you?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: What makes you so angry, good Sir William?

sp.speaker: Weal.
sp.p: Pray be pacify'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No, Sir, I'll not be pacify'd, Sir, with you, nor your Brother Rogue neither; he'll visit me to rob me agen, ha! What have you seen him, and advis'd him to it, ha? The other five hundred pounds. I'll lay him close an I catch him, a Thief.

sp.speaker: Weal.
sp.p: Nay, good Sir, consider, he's my Brother, and your Son.

sp.speaker: Old Sir.
sp.p: Sirrah, you lye.

sp.speaker: Weal.
sp.p: I have done, e're long you'll say the same by me.

sp.speaker: Old Sir.
sp.p: No, no, Tom, never; thou art my Son, my eldest Son, my best Son, I have no Son but thee, Tom.

sp.speaker: Weal.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, you must pardon me, my Mother was Vertuous. You must forgive poor Frank, he is your Son.

sp.speaker: Old Sir.
sp.p: Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Your own flesh and blood, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Old Sir.
sp.p: My flesh and blood, no Madam, but he robb'd me of my flesh and blood, my money.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Egad, and I am glad on't with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Old Sir.
sp.p: Fye, fye, you little Thief you, glad that a Son should rob his Father. But I'll tell you that you may judge the grief of a Parent, against you have Children, Tom or you, you little Rogue, for you will have Children; I'gad, I cou'd get you with Child my self. But as I was saying, I bred him at School, and it was a forward dirty Boy; from thence I sent him to the University; from the University to the Inns of Court, where in two years time, from a sober, grave, discreet youth, he grew the Debauch of the Town; roaring, drinking, whoring, fighting, were his daily Diversions: and because I wou'd not supply the Rogue with Moneys to maintain his Villanies, he comes down with a formal Recantation to me in the Country, where like a Rogue, a Cut-throat Thief in the Night, he robb'd me of five hundred pounds, and now he sends me word, he'll make such an other Visit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why, Sir William, methinks he has not wrong'd you in the least, you have sav'd Money by him, for sure 500 l. is but a small portion for a young Gentleman, and your Son.

sp.speaker: Weal.
sp.p: And wou'd still deserve the name, wou'd my Father but forgive him as a Son.

sp.speaker: Old Sir.
sp.p: Sirrah, Son me no Sons, he was my Son, but is not, nor any that plead for him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Come, come, Sir William, you were young once, and no doubt had your frollicks, and your share of that whoring, roaring and fighting you speak of, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Old Sir.
sp.p: Fye, fye, or if I had, I never robb'd my Father of five hundred pounds at a time, Girl, Girl: Consider the summ of five hundred pounds, before you plead for such a Rogue.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Good Cousen leave off, for the thoughts of five hundred pounds will put him so out of humour, we shall have no peace with him.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, Mr. Puzlecause the Lawyer is without, and desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Old Sir.
sp.p: Cods so, I, Tom, Tom, you must go with me, 'tis about drawing them Writings, about your Ladies Joynture. Well, God bless you both, and give you happiness.

sp.speaker: Weal.
sp.p: The man she likes needs not mistrust the blessing.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: The man she likes must not mistrust at all.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I cannot imagine what I have to do among all these sober, busie people; wou'd I cou'd find this mad young Wealthy, I fancy he and I shou'd be better Company than all these. Well, if this Town of London will not afford me one young Fellow, after my own heart, 'tis very hard. (aside.)
Sir William, when must the Wedding be, you keep me in expectation, I long to see the manner, though my Cousen by her gravity, I see, does not wish for it at all.

sp.speaker: Old Sir.
sp.p: O very suddenly, you little wagg you; what think you now of your own Wedding; what think you of an old fellow of sixty now; hold, hold, I mean fifty: a good hearty old fellow with abundance of Love and Money?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What think I of him! I had rather Marry your roaring, whoring Son with never a farthing, tho I never saw him yet.

sp.speaker: Old Sir.
sp.p: O fye, fye Child; why there's no safety with such lewd young fellows, you must think better; but come Tom, come Tom, Mr. Puzlecause will think it long. Good morrow Children, good morrow.

sp.speaker: Weal.
sp.p: Adieu, dear Madam. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Come Cousin, shall we visit the Widdow this morning? and engage her to the Exchange this afternoon. We'll have all our Fancies in your dress. Bless us, you deserve a Husband indeed, to be married within these two days, and not a Ribbond bought.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Upon my life Maria, I begin to be affraid: The beginning, and your Courtship indeed is diverting enough, but this Marriage i'll swear when it draws so nigh is a terrible thing. I pretend not to that ridiculous over-affected Modesty of being affraid of a man-bedfellow I like, but seriously it shocks me, when I consider I stake upon one cast, my good or my ill fortune for my life.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well Cousin, there is a hazard you know in all Games, and since we must be playing, faith I had as lieve lose at this as any Game.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But to the Widdow, she'll instruct you how
To steer your course under your Marriage Vow.
Tell you how far it must your Conscience bind,
And how far not, if Spouse shou'd prove unkind.
And as you pay your duty, how to know
When he fails in some matters due to you.
With these Instructions, never talk of fear,
The Widdow will make all things plain and clear.
And Faith Sophia, I dare swear for each,
We are as fit to learn, as she to teach. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I just receiv'd a message by Mr. Wealthy's man, Madam, that he will answer the Contents of your Letter, for he has earnest business with your Ladiship, and begs you not to fail at three exactly, at Mr. Spruce's Shop in the Exchange.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p:
I don't approve of his so often being there, though certainly had he any Intrigue with her, he wou'd not have the Impudence to appoint to meet me there. Well, 'tis a barbarous case that a Lady can't secure one man to her self, though she pay a very good price for him, and maintain him as her own Goods and Chattels; which is a great misfortune to us Widdows. For upon my life, your young fellows now a days, are scare-crow'd with the name of a Widdow, that we must either
marry old musty Batchelours, or secure some younger Brother by the magnetick Vertue of our Money. Betty, are the young Ladies up, think you?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Yes Madam, and I believe I hear 'em coming to visit you this morning.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Run, run, and wait 'em up stairs: Upon my life I had forgot my Complexion this morning; but they are Country Ladies, and may not miss it. Enter Sophia and Maria.
O dear, Ladies, I design'd this kindness to you, as soon as I cou'd possibly have drest my self.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Madam, your humble Servant; we made bold to wait on you; I hope we have not hindred your Devotions.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: O good Madam, I have been up these five hours. Betty, some Chairs; Ladies, pray sit down.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Madam, we came to desire your good Company to the Exchange this afternoon, to buy two or three suits of Ribbond for my Cousins Wedding. Your good Fancy will much improve her dress. Alas, we Country Ladies that so seldome come to Town, are the awkward'st Creatures: Dear Madam, you must assist us.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Alas Madam, since my unfortunate Widdowhood, dress has been the least of my thoughts: Nor cou'd I indeed ever boast of more than being clean, in the height of my prosperity; for the gaudy part of Dressing was still my Aversion: And I hope Ladies you will pardon me, if I must deny my self the satisfaction of waiting on you to a place that will so ill become my Condition to appear in, as the Exchange. Where I must meet my Wealthy, and with them 'twill be impossible. [aside.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: aside. Learn Sister, learn to Cant against you are a Widdow. If this be'nt a Hypocrite i'll be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Madam, you are Mistress of your self and time; but I thought the Exchange had been one of the innocent diversions of the Town, and might as well help out an afternoon, as the Play-house, or the Park, without incurring the danger of Censure in the least.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Ah Madam! 'tis a base malicious Town, and whoever will live with Reputation in it, must as nigh as possible avoid all those places.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: If all these are to be avoided, what difference is there between the Town and a Nunnery? Or what diversion does your Ladiship propose in Living.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p:
In Visits, Madam. 'Tis the grand affair of all Ladies of Quality,
to be exact in their days of giving and receiving Visits; high days of State; your Ladies Coller days as 'twere.— Betty, bring my Table-book, where you shall see how exact we are in our method, Madam, which is a mighty satisfaction to know ev'ry Ladies particular day of giving or receiving; so that consulting your Tables, you can never err. Let me see, Thursday last was my day of State; I think I had a great Court, Betty.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Twenty at least, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O Ridiculous! But certainly, Madam, so much Company shou'd rather be uneasie than diverting.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: O Madam, the Grandeur of the thing takes off all sort of uneasiness, tho you hated ev'ry one in the Company; nor are you oblig'd to talk to ev'ry one, no more than your rising acknowledgments at first. Now Madam, as thus, Alphabetically: Madam Attall on Monday; Madam Bareman on Tuesday; and so in the round, Madam Willdrink, Madam Willfull, Madam Wouldhaveit, Madam Wellenough, and my Lady Worstofall.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Your method, Madam, is extraordinary fine, but for my part, I'd sooner choose to walk by my self in the Fields, than be troubled with all this Company in their finest Apartments.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Is your Ladiship for one in the Garden this morning?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: We'll wait upon you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: No, pray Madam, indeed the Morning is inviting. [Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Spruce, and young Wealthy.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Ah, Mr. Wealthy!

sp.speaker: Weal.
sp.p: Well met, my dear Cuckold, and particular Friend.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Good Mr. Wealthy, if I may be so bold, whether intend you?

sp.speaker: Weal.
sp.p: Why, faith, to the Ordinary to Dinner.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Shall I prevent you, and perhaps to your satisfaction. If you will Dine with me and my Wife at home, I will entertain you with the Oddest and Idlest Resentment of a Brother Shop-keeper of mine, about his Wise, that can be.

sp.speaker: Weal.
sp.p: With all my heart.

(Aside.) This fellow is the happiest Cuckold living, so satisfy'd with himself, that he cannot believe there lives that Woman wou'd condescend to touch an other man, after the taste of his dear person. Aside.)
Well, I am contented to Dine with you, Mr. Spruce, but if you design not to take off the edge of my Appetite by suspence, let me know the business immediately.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
You know, Mr. Topknot, in the same row with me, you must
know the blockhead, ha, ha, ha. When Mr. Horner was the other day at his Shop, he heard him talk of a Journey he design'd on Sunday to Epsom, upon this Mr. Horner, as you or any man might do in my absence to my Wife, appointed a Visit to his Wife; as you, I say, might do to mine, a Gentleman and Customer to the Shop, to comfort her. I cannot tell you the occasion well, but this Blockhead coming home late a Sunday night, goes up directly to his Wives Chamber, where finding Mr. Horner laughing and playing with his Wife, no matter how, takes a ridiculous freak of Jealousie in his Noddle, falls into the violentest passion that could be, calling his Wife Whore; and Heaven knows what. The Gentleman seeing this, thought the fellow mad, and putting out the Candle, made his escape down Stairs, leaving the Blockhead railing and cursing, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Weal.
sp.p: But pray, Mr. Spruce, how has he dealt by his Wife?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: How! By my Conscience and Soul, Sir, he has turn'd her out of doors, like a Jealous Coxcomb as he is.

sp.speaker: Weal.
sp.p: O Barbarous!

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Now, Mr. Wealthy, this is amazement to me, I can't but believe these fellows have some Imperfection they are sensible of in themselves; Lord, if I were such a Coxcomb, how often must you and I have fallen out; though really, when I met my Wife and you, the other day, in a Coach alone, it did at first surprize me.

sp.speaker: Weal.
sp.p: Faith, and so did you us; but I satisfy'd you that was an accident.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: No more words, dear Mr. Wealthy, I don't mistrust my Wives Vertue, or my own Merit; but we are just at the door: Nan, is my Wife come home from the Change?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, she expects you at Dinner, but not so good Company with you.

sp.speaker: Weal.
sp.p: Pretty Mrs. Nanny.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Sir, shall I lead you in? [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: Your Servant Spruce. I have waited for you this half Hour: Mr. Wealthy, your humble Servant; you are a Stranger indeed.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Child, entertain Mr. Wealthy, till I go wash my Hands, and send up Dinner. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: Must we attribute this Visit to Chance, or good Nature? I doubt, if to good Nature, 'tis my Husbands.

sp.speaker: Weal.
sp.p: Faith, my Dear, you are in the right; but I design'd to have pleas'd my self at least with seeing you at three a Clock this Afternoon in the Change.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: If Mr. Spruce were as jealous as Mr. Topknot, indeed you might avoid seeing me any where, but there; But Heaven be prais'd he is of another Mould, and much more fit for my use.

sp.speaker: Weal.
sp.p: O he told me that Story. Shall I see you then to Night at home?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: With all my heart; but you'll fail, this is his Club Night, and ten to one but he's fuddl'd, but how open soever his Eyes are, I cast a Mist before 'em as easily as his understanding. At Nine the Garden gate shall be open, but don't fail; let me believe you think on me sometimes, by your not forgetting this.

sp.speaker: Weal.
sp.p: By this, and this, I will not. [Kisses Enter Spruce.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, My Friend Topknot wou'd have been at the Top of the House with half this. Jealous Coxcomb. Come, my Dear, will you come to Dinner. Another Fool wou'd have been Jealous of this now, I warrant; a civil Salute, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Weal.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: But what makes you laugh so, Prithee tell me?

sp.speaker: Weal.
sp.p: Why, this was your Wifes own Contrivance to try to make you Jealous; you rail'd so at Mr. Topknot: We have been Kissing ever since you went out, for fear we shou'd not be Kissing as you came in.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Have you so? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: 'Tis true Spouse, faith.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Well, do if you can; but the Dinner cools: Mr. Wealthy—

sp.speaker: Weal.
sp.l: Lead on, Sir.
May all thy Follies on thy Tribe attend,
And ev'ry Whoremaster have such a Friend. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Sly, Sophia, and Maria.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: 'TIs vain, I fear, to urge you further for your good Compapany to the Exchange, Madam, since your Reasons as well as Inclinations seem so averse to it.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Alas, Madam, I hope you'll excuse my incivility in not waiting on you; since really, Madam, I am so terrify'd at any thing may touch my Reputation, and the gravity of my Habit, I dare not appear there, tho in so very good Company.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, Heaven forgive me, I can't think Charitably of thee. Cousin, since we must venture by our selves into this bug-bear place among Men, Monsters, and Scandals: If we must suffer, Heaven have Mercy on our better part, I hope we shall have your Ladyship's Prayers; and for Mr. Wealthy, I declare, if we are Ravisht he deserves no better: a Lover, and go about Business with an old doating fellow of a Father, rather than wait upon his Mistress. Were he to be mine, I wou'd not Marry him this Fortnight, tho' I gnaw'd my Sheets to pieces.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Indeed, Madam, I doubt you wou'd relent, for Mr. Wealthy is really a very fine Gentleman, and the better he settles his Affairs now, tho' he robs himself of the Satisfaction of his Ladies Conversation, the more Enjoyment he proposes to himself afterwards; as all wise men do in so grand an Affair as Marriage.

sp.speaker: Mar,
sp.p: Indeed Madam, I am not come to those years of Discretion to like a wise man; for on the contrary, he is naturally my Aversion: and I dare avow for young Mr. Wealthy, whom I never yet saw, has more Wit in one of his Mad Frollicks, than his Brother's Spanish Gravity can be capable of.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Heaven send you may meet, for if what be true I have heard of him, by what I know of you, you might be excellent Company, and very fit for each others humours. Pray have you never heard of him, Madam.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, and seen him at a distance; a handsome young Gentleman indeed he is, but very Debauch'd, or very much wrong'd.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Madam, the Coach is at the Door.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Madam, your humble Servant, we'll try our Fancies by your Judgment, when we come back.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Ladies, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Your Ladiships humble Servant; no farther, adieu Madam. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Betty, make haste, and lay me out the Mantua and Petticoat I wore the other day, and take care to get a Hackney Coach to the Door when the Ladies are gone.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p:
Certainly if I should meet them in the Change; they can never
know me, my greatest fear is lest young Wealthy, who is fond of every new face, should meet them, and then I am undone, for 'twill be hard to lure him from so tempting a quarry, to a game I fear he is already cloy'd with: yet he knows the sign, and in good manners must obey it, tho against his Inclination.

div.head: SCENE II. The Exchange.
div.stage: Discovers Mrs. Spruce in her Shop. Enter Young Wealthy.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: I doubt I have over-stay'd my time; 'tis past Three, and the Widdow is not here, or else gone, which wou'd be a curst misfortune at this time: For to morrow I must make a visit to the old Gentleman, whatever comes of it: And his house of late has always been to me like a Tavern or a Baudy-house, bring but Ready Money, and you shall be well lookt after: Besides, the 10000 l. runs strangely in my head. There sits this nights diversion; a Cordial of the Widdows will make it much more agreeable. Ha! she's here. I think, by this light a brace of handsome Women. Enter Sophia and Maria.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: Ribbonds or Gloves, Madam; Gloves or Ribbonds.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Ha! they go to Mrs. Spruce's? have among you I faith Ladies: If the Widdow catch me, these are Cousins, nigh Relations.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Show us some of your newest fashion Ribbonds.

sp.speaker: Jan. Weal.
sp.p: Mrs. Spruce your Servant; are the things I bespoke done Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: What things does he mean? O the Devil fetch him! [Aside. No Sir, not yet, but if you'll send your man in the morning, or to night, to my house, he shall have 'em. Here Ladies, do you like this Ribbond, or this?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Cousin what say you? you don't mind 'em.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Cousin, what's the matter with my heart? Certainly the Devil's in that young fellow, or in me.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, have you met with your man think you?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: I have a strange Romantick thought in my head; what if I should fall in love with this young Creature at first sight, a pretty account I should give of my self to my Friends: I must find some opportunity to speak to her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O fye, these are too grave for our occasion, they must be for a young Ladies Wedding favours, the gayest thing you have.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: If a stranger may so far presume, not for your own I hope, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why Sir, wou'd you forbid the Banes?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Had I the same Interest as Inclination to it, Madam, you wou'd be in danger of it indeed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir, why are you in Love with me already?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Quick as her eyes I'gad: Why look you, Madam, plain Dealing's a Jewel: Let me first know what hopes my heart may have to build upon; whether you are a Predestinated Wife or not; and accordingly expect an answer from your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, no, no; Demonstration's no direct answer to any thing. I am resolv'd to be a Riddle to all my Lovers. They that can find the meaning of me take me. I must talk with this young fellow: Cousin take your own Fancy, as you have done already: I like none of 'em.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: As you have done already, O then she's the Bride, your Servant for that; 'tis kind and cunningly told, ha! I'gad these may be the two Ladies my Brother spoke of; I'll try. Well, Madam, to show you that I have an art that goes beyond unriddling any thing, I do positively know by the Stars, those Propitious Stars to me, that you are not Married nor engag'd: That you have not been in Town above six days: That the Gentleman's Name, your Cousin is to Marry, begins with a W. and that you lodge now—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Tell me that, and you're a Conjurer.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: That you lodge now— Let me fee— At the Lady Sly's in Covent Garden; ha! do you start, I'gad I am right.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And pray Sir, how came you to know this?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Art, Black Art, Madam, therefore at your own Proposals I claim you; or at least, the honour of being further acquainted.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why Sir, if you are Master of your Art, 'twill be in vain to deny you that, after having seen me, when you were so well acquainted with me, before I saw you.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: That's true, indeed Madam, but granted favours are much sweeter than stolen Fruits. Besides, Madam, there is really a necessity I should see you again, for should I at the first sight tell you a Romantick Tale of Flames and Darts, (tho you may well suspect your eyes,) yet you would not be apt to believe me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You are in the right, indeed Sir; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Therefore Madam, since you are prejudic'd against my first Essay, you ought in honour to allow a second, unless you mistrust the Justice of my Cause may prevail upon you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, if you grow serious upon business, adieu.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: And dare you venture to leave me thus, after avowing this passion, then I declare open War against you, and all those little dancing Cupids in your eyes. Assisted by the Spirits I command, those that inform'd me where you live, when you came, shall dance eternally Attendance; and wheresoe're among the numerous train of Fops your fancy settles, him they shall Plague. By one of these the nice shap'd youth that dances with you at Balls, shall have his Legs broke. The Sonniteer that chants his Amorous Notes, shall have his pretty mouth drawn to his Ears, whilst every Fop that levels dressing at you, shall certainly be tumbled in the Mire.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Till at the last, for want of better choice, I must take up with you. Bless us! a Conjurer! certainly I am a most unfortunate Creature, tho London I was told was a lewd place, to light upon the Devil at the first dash.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Therefore keep friends with him whilst you may.
sp.stage: Enter the Widdow, spys him, and pulls out her Handkerchief.
sp.p: 'Sdeath the Widdow. I know the sign, that curst Handkerchief; a plague on the Flag of Truce. When I was just giving Battel to the dear little Creature. Ay, ay, shake on; I can't see it yet.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Cousin will you go? I have bought what I design.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I wait you. Sir, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: The honour, Madam, to wait you to your Coach.
sp.stage: The Widdow crosses'em, and drops her Handkerchief, Wealthy takes it up.
sp.p: Madam, your Handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Not to trouble you Sir.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Jack, here take these things, and put 'em in the Coach.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Upon my life this is an Appointment; she's jealous by her answer: O that I were alone with her, I might disappoint her. Sir, the Lady's going.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Not whilest you are here Madam, or till I see you in the Coach.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: 'Twill be a trouble Sir, and our Coach is just at the Door.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: You shall be obey'd; when I see you next, I may challenge the honour of your acquaintance on other terms. Till then, fair one, Cross your self ev'ry Night, or my Spirits will play tricks with you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: None that can fright me, I'll watrant you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p:
Now for my Widdow, by that time I have appeased her, it will
be time to meet Mrs. Spruce, and by that time I have appear'd Mrs. Spruce, it will be time to take a Bottle, and by that time I have that in my head, I shall think I have manag'd my time very well. For tho on my Conscience I cou'd forsake Whoring to gain that dear little Creature, 'tis not like a wise man to leave off one Trade, without a certainty of living better on another. Your Servant Mrs. Spruce. Exit.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Mr. Shamtown is discover'd sitting by his Bed in his Night-Gown.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Jack, has it Rung at Convent-Garden yet?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis past five.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Pox on this Drinking! 'tis no matter tho, for I look so filthily puddled, I durst not have gone out. Lord, I am extravagantly hot; Jack, step where you know, tell 'em I keep my Chamber this afternoon, and shou'd be glad to see 'em.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: This is one of my masters high Intreagues; if Don Quixot's Dulcinea did not come of a better Family, I'll be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: I shou'd be very loth the Town shou'd know half what I am forc'd to trust this Rascal with: I have been now these 25 years (a damn'd long time to own) the chief Intreaguer of the Town, made such a figure, rais'd such emulation, I have been still the peak of every Poet, down from Sir Foplin to Sir Nice the Beau: There's not one Beauty fam'd in all the Town, to whom I have not paid some Gallantry; and thus much I must own, I never made address in all my life, where I was yet refus'd, to make the address indeed, but that was all. The speculative part has still been mine, and my misfortunes have been gaily drest; Celia indeed no sooner broke her Vow, but Cloe entertain'd me as her own, and married with my Rival in a month. Yet still I kept my Reputation up, and wheresoe're I came, fresh Billett Deux on Billet Deux receiv'd; sent by my self, Heav'n knows, unto my self, on my own Charges: yet now my Fate gives me a fairer prospect, and beautiful Sophia will be kind. I have been well receiv'd, and will go on: And tho I fight for once, once and no more, I'll venture Mr. Wealthy's surly temper. But wou'd my man wou'd come, for this is all but Speculative too, and I must Practise. Enter a Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, Mr. Littlegad's below, and bid me tell you he is come to wait on your Coushee.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, my Brother Beau, and in the Intrigue with me, I must speak with him, tho he must not stay to see my Paramour. Wait on him up, I must maintain my Character with him.

sp.speaker: Littl.
sp.p: Sir, your Servant; good Night to you, were now the properest. What, reading of a Secret?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: No, a Trifle; you may read it if you please, I just receiv'd it from a teazing poor Romantick Girl I promis'd Marriage to. I pity her, she writes a pretty stile.

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: Reads. Dear faithless man, Poor fool! For still you must be dear, dear to my Eyes, dear to my longing Heart; ah, why wou'd you betray me into Love? Why wou'd you promise me a Heaven in you, and take that Heaven away? Curse of her Eyes who have estrang'd your Heart! but O in vain, in vain I Curse the happiest Woman living. Pardon this trouble, Sir, it is the last. Boast you have broke a fond young Woman's heart, that lov'd too well to live, and live without you. Adieu. A very sad story. What no Superscription, no Direction?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, I had forgot to write it.

Aside. No, it came inclos'd; I am pester'd strangely with these idle things. I'm glad you're come, for tho I must beg your leave to receive a visit from a Lady of Quality that will be here presently, I must acquaint you with my design: I can prevail easily with the Widdow (who loves Dancing) to have a Ball at her House to morrow: 'Twill give us fresh opportunity to talk with the Ladies; and no small occasion to please them in our Dancing. You'll pardon, if I beg your leave a while: at night I'll meet at Wills, and order all. I'm much asham'd of this, but—

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: O Sir, the reason's Irresistible, no Complement, at Will's.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: At eight.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Sir, she—

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Rascal—

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Sir, she says 'tis Washing day, and she cann't come.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Damn her, go down.

sp.speaker: Mr. Littl.
sp.p: What, disappointed?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: She begs my pardon, 'tis her day of receiving Visits. A Pox of all Quality, 'sdeath I'll Marry and oblige no more, Sophia shall engross my heart for ever; and now we have time, Mr. Littlegad, tell me your mind, our time is short, our Reception has been extraordinary. Will you resolve at this Ball to slip Notes into their hands, that shall declare our honourable intentions.

sp.speaker: Mr. Littl.
sp.p: I wou'd do much for beautiful Maria, but Love has so much awe upon my Soul; besides, if they refuse we're undone, if they betray us worse, a Quarrel follows.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Sir, you're my friend, I'll trust you with my temper. By others want of manners in the Town, I have suffer'd in my Reputation, and therefore wou'd prevail upon my self to venture once: The Cause I'm sure deserves it, and Mr. Wealthy, I have oft discern'd, forces his temper to be Civil to me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Littl.
sp.p: Well Sir, you've been open with your friend: show me the Note you write, I'll show you mine.

lg.l: For why should she asham'd or angry be,
To be belov'd by me. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE the Back-Garden.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: My matters go swimmingly faith, I have appeas'd my Widdow, made my self half drunk, and fill'd my Pockets with money. To morrow will I rise with the Sun, and out-shine the Sun, wait on my Father like a Son; and if I can but set like the Sun in that dear little Thetis's lap, I shou'd make a very good day on't. However, since I am resolv'd to make honourable Love, I'll take my leave of Whoring to Night. This is Mrs. Spruce's back-door, and the fatal hour draws on, in which I must graft a fresh Branch on my friends Forehead. Ha! the Door shut! It us'd always to be open upon such occasions: I'll venture three gentle taps however, there may be a Scout nigh.

sp.speaker: Nanny.
sp.p: Who's that, Mr. Wealthy?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Dear Mrs. Nanny: A Maidenhead I'gad; a pox of her mistress.

sp.speaker: Nanny.
sp.p: My mistress has expected you this half hour; she's alone in the Parlour.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: With all my heart: But have you waited all this while in the Cold.

sp.speaker: Nanny.
sp.p: Indeed I thought it long before you came.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: But you'd have thought it longer, had you staid for one you Love.

sp.speaker: Nanny.
sp.p: Yes, if they came on purpose to see me.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Pretty little Rogue. The Child comes rarely on.

sp.speaker: Nanny.
sp.p: O fye Sir, what do you mean? Nay, pray Sir.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: What do I mean? To kiss those pretty little lips.

sp.speaker: Nanny.
sp.p: O dear Sir, my mistress. Enter Mrs. Spruce.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: O Madam, now I hope you'll own I am as good as my word.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spruce.
sp.p: Somewhat better methinks. Nanny go in. So Termagant, Mr. Wealthy, that you cou'd not have patience to walk in; I suppose my Maid told you I expected you in the Parlour.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Yes, yes, you'l cool my Courage: Fye, Madam, I was only Coaxing her for fear when you vex'd her at any time, she shou'd tell your Husband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sp.
sp.p: You know, Mr. Wealthy, my Husband is not so easily perswaded; but however, you boast of being as good as your word, I find, without a Bottle, you durst not have ventur'd.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Durst not; that word was never spoke to Spaniard yet, but forfeited a kiss that gave him it. Now Madam, since our time is short, and consequently very precious, pray let me have the honour to lead you into your own House.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: No, I'll swear you'll be Rude.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: No, I'll Swear I wont, but I'll be very Civil; when do you expect your Husband?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: Not these two hours. O Lord, indeed I am afraid I shall catch cold, the Night's very raw.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: I'gad you're in the right. Come along my dear. [Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Old Sir William and his Son.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Whereabouts are we Tom? 'tis somewhat dark.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Very nigh Covent Garden, Sir; we shall be at home presently.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: This Lawyer is a smart fellow, Tom, he has drawn up these Writings concisely, and full. Ah, that Rogue Frank, he might have done this, if he had follow'd his Studies, an idle Rogue, and sav'd me this Charge: But he must be fine, he must be a Wit, a Beau, Pox on him.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Sir, I believe it is yet in your power to reclaim him; he has seen the Vices of the Town, and no doubt is sick of them: Cou'd he but get a Competence to live.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Well Sir, and you'll have me settle an Estate upon him; I'll settle him in Newgate first, a Vagabond.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Nay, pray Sir, hear me.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No, Sir, thank God I've taken care of you. I've settled you, I'll part with no more money.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Sir, you shall not part with a Groat.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Upon my word you shant, and yet make him happy.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: He has been a Rebellious Boy, but the tenderness of a Father— Well, tell me how, for I wou'd do him all the kindness I cou'd without Charges.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Sir, give him the liberty of your House, Countenance him as your Son, and let him address himself to young Maria.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Here's a Snake in my bosom; what, throw away my little pretty Maria with 10000 l. too. No, thank you Sir, I'll find a better match; what, betray my trust: Marry her to a Ranting, Roaring Bully. What, give her the Pox? Ah, Sirrah! What if I have a mind to marry her my self?

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Sir, you'll pardon me if I say, methinks you are too old to think of marriage.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No, Sirrah, not so old as the young debauch'd Rascals of the Town, rotten before they are ripe. Sirrah, provoke me any more, speak of this match any more, I'll Marry, get a Child, and disinherit you both; and so come along.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Sir, I'll follow you, and shall watch you too, for shou'd he marry, a Child may be got without his help.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What Sirrah, do you mutter?

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Mutter, no Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No Sir, come along. [Exeunt.

div.stage: The Scene draws, and discovers the Garden-door. Enter young Wealthy and Mrs. Spruce.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Adieu, dear Mrs. Spruce, you'll send that Linnen I bespoke, to morrow early.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: Yes, but not by my Maid. [Enter Mr. Spruce Drunk.
My Husband, if ever he is Jealous 'tis in his Drink. Dear Mr. Wealthy adieu, how will you escape him?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: How the Devil do I know: 'Sdeath, I'll stand against this Pump.

sp.speaker: Mr. Spr.
sp.p: Whereabouts am I? Is not this my back door? I am somewhat Drunk; 'tis a beastly thing above once a month, and that's my stint; but I'll please her with the Song I learnt: Tell me no more of Glory or Story. She loves a soft Song. Tell me no more of Glory. No Canary, pox of that slip; I have all dirted my face.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: 'Sdeath I think I had best run for it now. Pox of his Agility, he's up already: if he comes to the Pump, i'm undone.

sp.speaker: Mr. Spr.
sp.p: Let me see, here's a Pump hereabouts.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Wou'd it were in your Guts.

sp.speaker: Mr. Spr.
sp.p: I must clean my self, that I may not disgust my Wife, and make her think indifferently of my Person. Pox on't, they have taken away the handle: O here it is.

div.stage: Gropes up and down, and takes hold of Mr. Wealthy's hand instead of the Pump.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: If he discovers me i'll knock him down, and then I shall pass for a Thief. The Dog will pull my Arm off.

sp.speaker: Mr. Spr.
sp.p: Zounds the Pump's dry.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: 'Sdeath I have a Bottle of Orange Flower Water his Wife presented me. Spirts the Orange Flower Water in his face.

sp.speaker: Mr. Spr.
sp.p: O does it come; delicate Water faith: So now for my Wife: Let me see, where's the Key. Tell me no more of Glory, too to Court— Exit.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: A sensless drunken Dog, not know a man from a Pump; this was a good scape, I shou'd have been loth to have Convinc'd him that he was a Cuckold. Let him doat on, 'tis late; shall I go home so sober, I shall Dream of the Devil all Night? no, the other Bottle.

lg.l: Good Wine does all our Satisfaction bring.
But t'other Bottle is a Glorious thing. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Maria alone in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: WHat would I give to know whether I am really in Love with that young fellow or not; let me examine my self. I am very angry with that Woman that came to meet him; methinks I could beat her, yet I could not beat him. I long to see him again too; and I am afraid I should be loth to part with him. Mercy upon me, these are very ill Signs.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: What Musing Maria? Good morning to your serious Meditations: Pray your Thought?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: If you'll promise not to laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: What, the pretty young fellow reigns still in your fancy: What, four and twenty hours together? On my Conscience you are constant; ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Laugh on, laugh on! Who was caught first?

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: But fye upon you, I thought you would have reserved your heart for young Mr. Wealthy; and this Gentleman you saw was engag'd.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Would I knew where, I'd plague her however; but if he should be in Love with her I'm undone.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: To clear that doubt Girl, I'll tell thee News shall make thee bless me for it: That Lady your Rival, Madam, is our Individual, Grave, Formal, Hippocritical Widdow.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Impossible, or how should you know it?

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: Walking last Night in the Balcony-room, somewhat impatient of Mr. Wealthys return, I heard a Hackney-Coach stop, whence bolted out the very Figure we saw in the Change, and my Curiosity found afterwards to be the Widdow.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O this Ephesian Dame, shall she devour my Souldier; no, I'll vex every vein of her Heart. I'll Dog her every day, that when she meets him next, I'll meet him too, and turn her to her proper use, Procuring; I'll trace the old Fox till I find out her Young ones.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: Poor Girl, she's sar gone.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: A Witch: Pardon me Ladies, if I dare not go to a place that so ill becomes the Gravity of my Habit. [Musick within the Garden.
What Serenading Fools are these?

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: You're strangely out of humour, what if it should be a morning Serenade from our two Church-men, in order to the Ball we are to have this Evening? You remember the Part you are to Act.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Iudeed you must pardon me, I shall be out.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: I grow sick of mine too; but heark, a Song. [Song after it.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Mr. Wealthy do we owe our thanks to you.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: This Madam, as the gentlest way I cou'd, I chose to let you know my bold request; Musick and Beauty seem so nigh a kin; such equal charmers sure what one desires, the other can't deny; to morrow be the day; joyn to that natural goodness of your Soul; your kind endearing Promises and Vows, put on the Deity you are to me, descend and perfect all my hopes to morrow.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Sir, I confess it is a fault to blush, in answering what I have so often promised; but you must pardon both, since I must confess, so soon you have surpriz'd me, I own you Conquerour o're all my heart, but beg as yet you would not use your power; allow my Virgin fears some time to fly, I shall in honour yield without surprize.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Allow for all my Wracks of Passion; for all my broken hours and nights of rest. Allow for the Impatience of my Love, that counts all hours Ages till to morrow, and put this in the ballance with your fears: If it be yet too light, I'll kneel to beg a blessing great as this.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What a Pox, is the fellow going to Prayers, or to say Grace to to morrows Feast? Child, Child, time is short, all things settled, and London's a Wicked Place, therefore prepare to look the Parson boldly in the face, and in grace of peace, i'll see you married, and then—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: But Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Stop her mouth Boy, she'll cry 'tis too soon, or some mischief or other: Where's my little Maggot this morning? she'd put off such a business I warrant you; uh 'tis a parlous Quean.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Well, I will plague the Widdow and this old fellow. Good morning to you Sir William, you see they're got together with a villanous
design to make you a Grandfather, and then you'll look so old, Sir William, 'tis a pity; for now you look brisk enough for the youngest Maid in Town; methinks I could fall in Love with you my self.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Think you so, my little Maggot, not so old but I can play at creep Mouse yet; creep Mouse, creep, catch her, catch her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, nay, nay, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why, you little Eyes, you little Nose, you little Mouth, you little— No, no, you're for young Rogues; we old wholsome fellows, with good Hearts, sound Lungs, hum, hum: no, no, we can't pass now a days. Tom, I heard Musick here just now, was it yours Tom? Prithee, let's have a Song there; gad, I'm very merry this morning. Adsbodkins, I'll sing thee a Song my self, Girl. Now you shall hear, now Huswife, an old fellow; adslid, hum, hum.

div.stage: After several ridiculous Grimaces, Sir William Sings.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O brave, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ah, you little Rogue! Creep Mouse creep, catch her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Fye, fye, Sir William, you'll make me angry.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why then be pleas'd again, you little baggage, ah.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Come, Sir William, let's see if you're as good at Dancing as you are at Singing; come Sir, I'll Dance with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Art thou for a Hoy tite Rogue? Come, strike up then.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Margery Crey.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Oh, fye, fye.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Come, come. [They Dance.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: O this unmerciful Jade.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: No matter, Madam, he likes it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: About, about, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Merry and Wise; Wise Child, Merry and Wise Puh.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: Sir William, you grow young again; you trip it like any Fairy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh fye upon him, he has put me so out of breath, I shant be able to Dance this Evening.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: And yet I am old, I warrant you, ha? You had rather marry my Wicked Debauch'd Son Frank, you little Eyes, you little Nose, creep Mouse creep.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, I yield Sir William now, but I'll try your Courage at the Ball.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p:
But what the Devils the meaning of these Balls? What a
Pox do these fellows do here? Here they tell me a Story of the Honour of my former acquaintance, when I never saw them but once, when I was last in Town, at a Coffee-house, and now at Church.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: And think you not that enough, Sir, to take hold of, when it will introduce them into so good Company as these fair Ladies?

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: Still there Tom?— Cousin.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Good Sir William, and you Mr. Wealthy, do not quarrel at our good Fortune what e're you think; if I were sure of meeting such good Company, I'd go to Church every hour in the day; besides they're the Widdows acquaintance; we are oblig'd to her as well as you for their Company and the Ball we are to have; where, for all this, you must Dance to night.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Dance! you little Eyes you; ay, and Dance forty such Limberhamm'd fellows as these dead still: What, because this great fellow here makes me look a little old, and the Cares of the World makes me look somewhat grey before my time, do you think I'll be laid aside; adsbodikins if you will Dance, Dance me a good round Country frisk: Pox o your Minutes and Bore's (what d'ye call'em) Dances only invented for your smooth pac'd pocky French fellows: Ounds, a good round Country Jigg would shake em all to pieces.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: True Sir; but as brittle ware as they are, they crack many a Ladies reputation, without ever hazzarding their own; and ought no more to be suffer'd in Families than Eunuchs, who, however unmann'd, can both divert and disgrace their Ladies if they please.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nay, sure Mr. Wealthy now you're too severe.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Not a bit, faith Tom, I hate these young old fellows mortally.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: On my Conscience 'tis Scandalum Magnatum, were I a man so wrong'd, I'd Cuckold you to disprove you; but here comes the Widdow, I'll swear I'll tell.

Oh Madam, would you believe it? This Mr. Wealthy is the vilest man, he says he believes Mr. Shamtown and Mr. Littlegad are Eunuchs, as if that your Ladiship, that has known what a real man is, would keep such Company, or suffer them to come into your House.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ha, ha, why you little eyes you, what spare no body? She's a Wag Madam, she's a Wag.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: I like her humour the better; but Mr. Wealthy, indeed you must give me leave to take the part of this young Lady, in behalf of the young Gentlemen who are men of extraordinary Parts, upon my word.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: I doubt it not Madam, since your Ladiship is so well acquainted with them and their Parts.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Nay, nay, the men may pass; but what a Pox is that young old fellow, that peeps out of his Perriwig like an Owl out of a Bush.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: O Damn him, an Antiquated Beau, aiming to be, but never in the fashion; saucy enough to Ape the Noblest man, but wrongs him as much as a damn'd Country sign did King Charles the Second; would make you believe he is a Linguist, but really pickt up the bits of Languages, by begging his way home when he was abroad. In short, to be Pawn Broker to a Basset Table, is the Top of his Pretensions.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Upon my word, Mr. Wealthy, 'tis malice, for I receiv'd just now a very pretty Epistle from them, and am in Love with the design of changing our Ball, among our selves, into a harmless Masquerade, where every one may please their fancy in expressing either their humours or desires, by their dress; and so, though we know our full Company, be puzled to find out each other.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Troth, that's pretty indeed.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: 'Twill help the merriment, no doubt; I like the humour.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: This is a Trick by Heav'n! I beg your Pardon, Madam; I confess, since we are so few, and we know all the Company, I cant find out the Jest of Masquerading; to drive on an Intrigue or so, I grant you.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: Or to express our humours, by our dress, is full as well.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, I have done.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir William, what say you?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: With all my heart, i'faith, I'll Masquerade you; and if I find you out, you little eyes you, I will so creep mouse you. But what a Pox, we an't enough, we shall want Company.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: If you are all agreed, I'll send them word; and by the way, desire Mr. Spruce and his fair Lady's Company, and so please you.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Agreed, agreed; come, be brisk Tom, let us be merry to Night, and please Heav'n, to morrow I'll settle the best part of my Estate upon thee, and thee upon her, i'faith Tom; and the rest my little eyes shall have if she will, and there's my care over.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: Indeed Sir William, I must—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I know it my dear Child, I know it, all Women must; take her aside Tom, and walk with her in the Garden, and tell her some fine things. Tell her she must, and where she must, and when she must, and how she must; go, go Tom, tell her all. What are you running away, you little eyes you? What, you must too, ha?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: So must you too, Sir William, when you can; I must go to my Chamber and study my dress for the Masquerade, and some mischief against that black Devil, for I hate the sight of her. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Get you gone you little Maggot, you little; um I could. The Devil's in her I think, I never come nigh her but I fancy, my self twenty again.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: I have observ'd this old fellow is in Love with her; I'll try him, and help too if I can, for if young Wealthy should as he has threatned, their humours will so hit, I shall certainly lose him. Sir William, if you'll pardon me, I'll tell you something I have observ'd; and I believe I may serve you in it with that young Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What says my Widdow, with that young Lady, ha?

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: What think you Sir? would she not be a comfort to your Age? would not a Bedfellow so sweet, so free, so gay, so witty, lovely, and so young, renew your life, and give you a fresh Lease? What think you Sir, be ye open?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Think Widdow? Gad, I know not what to think, what her little Eyes mine, her little Nose mine, her little Mouth mine, nay, her little all mine. Ah, Widdow, I'll give thee five hundred pound let me live to see that day, I'll Article immediately Widdow; there, there's my hand on't; by the Lord Harry— but the Money's returnable if not.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Agreed, and I accept your Generosity. But then, unless you follow my advice, you ruin all my measures. In the first place, you must resolve to stay in Town; in the next, your youngest Son, whom every body Loves, they say that sees him, must be banish'd, if e're he pays his Duty as he threatned.—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Banish'd! Ounds, I'll hang him Widdow, a Rogue. I have enough to hang him when e're I please: Why, he robb'd me of five hundred pounds, Widdow.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: What then, you would not hang your Son.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Let him keep off then, let him keep off then, a Dog; but my dear Widdow, at her, my dear Widdow, tell her fine things, my dear Widdow. What a fine thing it is to have a great Estate, my dear Widdow, and to reign Mistress of a House and Family, my dear Widdow: Tickle her my dear Widdow, and I'll tickle her, my dear Widdow; hum. Methinks I have got her already; but Widdow, Widdow, rail damnably at all young fellows.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: I'll warrant you Sir; how his old bones dance. Well, Sir William, I'll sound her presently, she's gone to her Chamber, and I'll to her instantly, and after Dinner I'll tell you more.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Go, go, go, five hundred pound Widdow go; go Widdow, rail at all young Rogues. [Exit Widd.]

Pox on them rotten Rogues, that can neither Drink nor Whore, and yet set up for both, with weak Hams, slackned Nerves, shaking Hands, and flannel Shirts, before they're five and twenty. I'll shew them what an old fellow can do. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: So, this Letter will I show or drop before the Widdow: No, I'll shew it her, make her my Confident, as if it came from the Gentleman I met in the Exchange. There needs no Name; and though she knows his Hand, if she be Jealous, she'll believe that Counterseit for fear of her. It begs I'de meet him there: I'll ask her Counsel, and observe her looks; if she be mov'd, my Cousin's in the right. Then if she goes to meet him in my stead, I'll Masque my self, and dog her to the place, and let him Judge whatever he thinks fit. I'll tell him that I came to vex them both.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Madam, the Widdow.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Wait upon her up, she leaps into my Net; I'll plague her very Heart.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Your Servant, Madam, still thinking on your Dress? I see you'll surprize us all with your fancy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No Madam, I was otherwise employed; for being a perfect stranger to this Town, I was something troubled in my self to know whether I have met with a Civility or an Affront.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Explain your self, good Madam; not from me I hope, nor any of my Servants.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Not in the least; so far from that, dear Madam, you are the only person in the World I'll trust, or ask advice of.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: You make me wonder.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You know how earnestly my Cousin and I entreated your good Company last night, till you convinc'd us how unfit it was for one so much afflicted, to be seen in naughty places, like the New Exchange.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: What means she? aside.
Well Madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: However after begging of your Prayers, and saying of our own, with aking hearts, you know we went; nay, and are come off alive.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Good Madam on.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Indeed there was much Company and fine, and had your Ladyship been there, I'm sure you'd say the same.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: I doubt it not Madam. The Devil, what does she mean?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But grief you know Madam, however it may lull it self at home with Balls, or harmless Musick to divert, ought not to appear in publick, but in tears; that robb'd us of your company, dear Madam.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: And is it that disturbs her?— 'Tis that I fear's the incivility which you suspect.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, on my Life; swear to be secret and I'll tell you all.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: I vow: I would she would begin.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: There was a young and really handsome Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Ha, goes it there?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What says your Ladiship?

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Nothing Madam, a handsom Gentleman you said.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, you'd have said so had you seen him.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Very likely; but what of him?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Waiting, as afterwards, I found too plain, for better company, to pass the time, began to talk with me.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Not rudely, I hope— This Devil could not know me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: She's stirr'd— so far from that, even at first sight, nay, the first words he spoke, were Raptures, Flames and Darts; I know not what, but mixt with much Civility and Wit.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: These are the common Gallantries you meet; the young and beautiful must bear with this.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: More Madam, he told me where I lodg'd, when I came hither, my Cousins Marriage, and the first letter of her Husbands Name.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: And not his own.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, but he'd wait on me he said, and I believe him, for I just received this Letter by his Servant to my Maid, which I can construe nothing but affront; for sure he thinks me such another Prize as the Lewd Minx he met.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Impossible; pray let me see it. By Heav'ns, this is none of his Hand! But that was Jealousie of me, a trick I scorn him for.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: She srets: Nay, Madam, let not your Zeal for me disorder you so much, it is not worth your Anger, nor my Notice.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: But Madam, such a Villain, at the first sight, without the least acquaintance, to offer to request a second meeting of a young Lady in that open place, is so much impudence, such an affront, it shocks a modest Woman but to think it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And then so basely too, to rail at her; I know he came tomeet, and curse her too. If you read on Madam, you'll find he curses; curses her, the occasion of our parting, and rails at her impertinence and love.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Oh base, base, Madam, monstrous base. This they are all, but he the basest living.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, dear Madam.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Indeed I am too blame to wonder at it; I'll curb the just resentments of my heart, and strike at this to speak for old Sir William.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Hang her, I'm vext to see her fret so much, for I shall love him more now out of spight; but if I ne're should see him— oh that's sad, would he would write indeed.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Madam, you ask'd advice, if you'll accept it, judge but of this; you are young, and in a place so pester'd with Intrigues, may unawares your inclination, fix on one may seem deserving in your eye: But, believe me Madam, among the vain young flatterers o'th' Age

lg.l: The Monsters, we fond Women Lovers call,
There's not one grain of truth.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Among them all.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: She mocks me certainly, but I'll observe her. No, for their Folly, Vanity and Pride, exceed the most ridioulous of us; and for their Vows, their Conscience, or their Honour, a man on this side forty, is markt a fool, that ever meant a true word to a Woman.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Indeed.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: By Sympathy the young affect the young, and she's the happy Woman whose kind Lot directs her where those Vanities are past, and Marries with the Anoient and Discreet. Were I to choose, I beg your Cousins pardon, I should prefer Sir William 'fore the Son.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Madam, I sent your Letters, and had answer they will be here.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: I come, Madam, you'll be ready immediately.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'll wait on you, you have the Letter.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, at your Service.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, pray, keep it Madam; I fear I shall be troubled still with more; if it be so, i'll beg your Ladyship so far as in a Mask, to venture with me, and find out who it is, you can't deny me.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: You shall command me Madam, to my wish. I'll ruine this and him. Your Servant Madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: So, 'twas her he met, her folly and her jealousie betray'd it; by her grave counsel and railing at young men surely Sir William taught her, I'll find that out: Wou'd I as easily cou'd find a way to meet with him; he talkt of visiting, which with a formal shew as to the Widdow, if he has good nature, may be meant to me; I'd thank him for't: However, since I am resolv'd to see him, I'll trace and haunt the Widdow every hour, bribe every Maid she has, know all she does, read all her Notes, if Gold will break the Seals.

lg.l: Not slip the least of any likely hint,
And then if all should fail, the Devil's in't.

div.head: SCENE a Chamber.
div.stage: Discovers Mr. Shamtown Dressing. Enter Mr. Littlegad.

sp.speaker: Littl.
sp.p: How, Mr. Shamtown not yet equipt? Impossible your fancy should be pall'd: I never yet in my whole half years travel, met an Italian could for humour match you. What can it mean, the Product must be wonderful.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: A trifle Sir to yours, Judge when you see it; 'tis odd indeed, but strikes upon a string, that will declare my Love and Sufferings. You're for the Camp, methinks 'tis very fine, and I believe will take Maria's humour.

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: Do you sincerely think 'twill please the Ladies? Sir, 'tis the composition of my Travels, more than three Kingdoms claim a right to it: My Perriwig I bought in Paris, my Cravat at Venice, my other Linnen in Flanders, my Gloves at Rome, my Wastcoat at Naples, and my Sword is a Milanese.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: You give a good account, Sir, of your Travels.

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: If you'll believe me Sir, I went on purpose, that being at each place, what was their Pride, I might compare with the most nicely drest.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, the Taylor is come with your Habit.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Bid him wait without.

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: What, shant I see you dress'd; how shall I know you at the Ball?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: O never fear, by the discription I gave you'll know me. We must not go together; pray for our Success; I'll meet you there immediately.

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: Adieu. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Upon my life I go with an aking heart, for should I be embarass'd with a confounded accident as I was at the last Ball, concerning that damn'd China Jar, I do not believe I should be able to sustain it. Pox on't, I've renounc'd back Capers ever since. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: So, now for my Mistriss and my Father, methinks I am a very pretty fellow; certainly this old fellow wont have the heart to turn me out of doors, and disgrace a Gentleman in his new Cloaths. But plague of his Country breeding, he'll swear I stole them, or at least come to steal money of him to pay for them, and then sans ceremony out goes the Reprobate Son, if not tost in a Blanket; and egad if he does, I have often promis'd the Widdow, I'll marry her, make the House my own, and turn him out in the dead of a damn'd thundring Rainy Night, and nothing but Lightning to guide him to another Lodging; or deliver him to the Watch for a House-breaker; and there's trick for tricks. What a Pox is it to him. Ha, what's here Fiddles? [Flourish Musick.

Gad, I believe they are married to day; that's well, the Devils in him if he be'nt civil at such a time. Well, since I must have a pluck at the Golden Fruit, I must venture waking the Old Dragon. [Knocks, enter a Boy.
Is Sir William Wealthy within Sir?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes Sir, but there's a great deal of Company, I believe he's not to be spoke with.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: What means the Musick I heard, is his Son married?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No, Sir, 'tis a Ball.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Well Sir, I know them all, if you please to shew me up—

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, they are all in Masquerade.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: So much the better; canst thou lend me a Masque, here's a Crown for thee good Lad.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes Sir, please to walk in, I believe I can. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE a Hall.
div.stage: Discovers the Masquers, Wealthy, Shamtown, Littlegad, Maria, Sophia, Spruce, Mrs. Spruce.

sp.speaker: Mr. Spr.
sp.p: Methinks faith, this is a pretty Frollick, my Wise came in one Coach and I in another, and egad, among all this good Company, I know not which is she. Ah, there's many a Jealous fool in our Change, would be hang'd before he'd trust his Wife thus, for fear of being a Cuckold, forsooth: However, I'll look out for her, sure this is she, pray Madam, What is your inclination by your Dress.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: This must be my Husband, by that ingenious fancy; he would be an Alderman I find; if he were Knighted 'twould be well enough, for I would be a Lady, ride in an Aldermans great Iron-workt ratling guilt Coach, and laugh at every body on foot.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Which of these three's Sophia? I can't guess but that in the Nuns Habit, by her Stature, must be Maria; on and prosper, my dress may plead for me. Oh my sad heart.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Which of the Coxcombs is this? a pretty way to tell his Passion, and I must witness to't. Pox of all their Masking to this dumb piece of Courtship, and may be to my Mistriss. I shall make that heart bleed afresh, if it aim there; and he goes right, for that I'm sure is she.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: Was ever so ridiculous a sight? this must be my Lover, and sure that Jealous Spaniard must be Tom. Good Sir, how many hearts have you left whole, if a young Country Virgin should unfortunately Love you? Or is your Mistriss Cruel, you look so pale on it?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Ah! Fair one! Let this Emblem of grief speak what I dare but think.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Madam, the man's in Love, can you not guess.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: Good, churlish Sir, who are you? And why in this Spanish Habit.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p:
It suits my temper best, Madam; I hate ridiculous Fops that change their fashions, to Court their Mistress, in variety: I am still the same, constant and ever loving; but if provok'd, as Jealous as Usurpers. I'de stab more hearts than Cupid has of his, and lay them bleeding at my Mistriss Feet. Nor is't unjust, to think the man that Loves like me beyond a man, should, if once wrong'd, do things beyond
his reason. This Madam, whosoe're you are's my Character, and yet there lives not such a Slave as I am.

sp.speaker: Sop.
