sp.p: 'Tis a good one, less Jealousie tho' were better, for I would choose a life wholly retired from all the World, but that dear man I lov'd, where there were left no room for Jealousie, or groundless fears to interrupt our Love, but live long and happy days, and dye together.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: Ah, Fair one! Would the Goddess I adore
Speak but such words, my Wounds would bleed no more.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Good bloody Bones keep off.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: Fye, Spaniard, do not over Act your Part.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: This must be Wealthy, i'll take a fitter time.

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: Cruel Devotress, will you rob the World of the but one sweet Angel they have left, to add to those vast Millions are above? Let me prevail, throw off this Garb of sorrow; shine out the Glorious Princess of the Earth; in every Princes Court i'll sing your Praise, and with my Sword immortalize your Name: The stubborn'st Knight alive shall own your Beauty, Transcendent o're the Mistriss of his heart.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh Vanity! Be gone, you Court that Honour which your Sword must win, more than the Mistriss you pretend to fight for; and I have bid adieu to all the World.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: That Nun must be Maria, and she, i'll swear, belys her inclinations; that Villain Wealthy knows it. That Phantastick thing must be Mr. Shamtown, but which of them is Wealthy, which Mr. Littlegad, I cannot guess; that must be Spruce, but where is Old Sir William?

div.stage: Enter Sir William like a Huntsman.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ye, la, ho, ho, hey, Jouler, oux ther, oux hey, Ranter hey.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir William, Sir William.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Who are you? what my little eyes, little Nose, little mouth. What a Pox a Nun, is that thy Choice then, i'll build Churches.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: How came it your Dogs are not in Masquerade too?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What a Pox is here with all these bloody hearts? Oux, oux, there, ye la ho.

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: I wonder a man of your years should Hunt in Ladies Chambers.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ye la ho oux, there oux too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He may follow the scent, but can never keep up with his Game.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What, all upon me, nay then, take off your Dogs.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: What the Devil's the meaning of this, are they all mad, Nuns, Aldermen, Huntsmen, Heroes, Milk-maids, Ladies? And what a Pox, the man in the Almanack? I'll mix in the Crowd, and look out for my little one.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Ladies, if you'll be pleas'd to seat your selves, here's one will entertain you with a Song.

sp.speaker: Sop. Mar. Widd.
sp.p: With all our Hearts.

div.stage: SONG. Every now and then Sir William hollows and Interrupts them.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, Sir, you spoil the Song.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Pox o'th' Song, there's more Musick in this; let us Dance.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Agreed, agreed; but what Dance?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why, the Frier upon the Nun: Where's my little Nun? Who are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: My Servant, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Bless me, who is it?— I never saw him before. Let us reckon our number, how many should we be?

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Mind.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine.— The Devil, the Devil; this fellow will run away with half the House. Ounds, Sir, who are you? If you are the Devil tell us so, that we may open the Doors and Windows, and give you free passage; it must needs be the Devil, I have heard of such a business. Ay, ay, 'tis the Devil.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: No Sir, I am no Devil, but your Son.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: You lye you Dog, you're worse than the Devil. Thieves, Murder, Rogues, I am undone, Lock up my Doors, call a Constable, I am undone.

sp.speaker: Eld Weal.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Father, for shame; before all this Company.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Sir William, fye, consider.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: A Rogue, he's come to rob me; what the Devil does he here else?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: With your leave you do me wrong, I am neither come to beg, borrow, nor steal, as you may see; for your five hundred pounds I'am able to pay you, and then I owe you nothing but your begetting me, and may be I repent that as much as you; and so Sir good b'y. I came to have ask'd your blessing had you pleas'd.— Now will he call me back.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Who's that, my Son Frank?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Yes, yes, this is your Son Frank.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Frank, why come hither you Rascal you.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: O the blessing of a kind Father.— Your blessing Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ah, thou hast been a Rogue Frank, but I forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Then the Debt's paid.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What say you?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: I thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: But where didst thou get this money Frank, is it all Current? Let's see Frank.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Brother, I am heartily glad to see you, I hear you are to be married. Pray which of all these fair Ladies will honour me with the Name of Brother?

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: This; and she does indeed.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Joy to you both.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: This is her Cousin Brother.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: All lovely kindred, faith, with your leave, sweet one.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Cousin.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nay, I pity you.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Madam, I hope you'll pardon this Intrusion.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: On any account but this.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Your Servant Mrs. Spruce.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Ah smack her Mr. Wealthy.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ay, ay, smack; he'll smack her; ah 'tis a Dog, a handsom Dog, and a strong Dog. But he's a Rogue, a damn'd Rogue, I must look to him, he'll rob me again else when his money's gone.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: An extraordinary fancy this of yours Sir.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: To Divert the Ladies Sir.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: A Hero too. Mr. Littlegad you've wondrous fancy; Ladies, you were talking of a Dance, let me not hinder you.— By your leave Mr. Hero, if I beg this Lady as a Relation for my Partner.

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: Damn him, I shall miss my opportunity.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why Sirrah, Sirrah, robbing me already, ha.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, no, Sir William, I danc'd with you in the morning.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Gad a mercy Nuns flesh, i'll creep mouse you for this; and for that i'll send my Rogue Frank packing, well I'll sit by and see you. Tom, Tom, to the Widdow: Strike up there, who leads?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Mr. Spruce, sure none but Mr. Spruce.

sp.speaker: Mr. Spr.
sp.p: Your Servant Ladies.

div.stage: Dance: All the Dance Sir William sits upon the ground, and every time Maria comes by him, catches at her Petticoat.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: This must be the time.
sp.stage: Offers to slip a Note into Sophia's hand, she strikes it down, Sir William snatches it up and looks on it.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: What Insolence is this.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Death and Hell.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Treason Tom, Treason! Ounds, a Plot upon your Mistriss; a Plague of these bleeding Hearts.

div.stage: [Dance breaks off, Eldest Wealthy takes the Note.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Do you own this? [To Shamtown.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: What if I did Sir?

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: I'de pay the Postage. [Strikes him.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: God a mercy Tom: Sir, you are a Son of a Whore; well said Tom. [All shriek and run out but the Widdow.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: For Heav'ns sake, Gentlemen, consider where you are; you have frighted all the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Damn you, speak English.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: What said he Frank, [Frank whispers him.
Very well. Madam, I beg your pardon if I have gone beyond the Rules of Civility, impute it to the ill manners of your friends.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Yes faith, Widdow, I beg your Pardon, but that fellow is a Son of a Whore, that's certain. But where's my little Nun? 'sbud, they han't run away with her too?

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: They are within Sir William, but half dead with the fright.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I'll go comfort her, but that fellow, Widdow, is a Son of a Whore. Let us in, let us in, a damn'd Son of a Whore. [Exeunt Widdow and Sir William.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Behind Southampton-house you say, at six exactly.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: So their fury tells us if it hold.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Brother, you must not be engag'd in this, but of that more anon. I'll not stay here to Night, we shall be prevented. Boy, call a Coach to the back door; make haste and fetch my Cloak and other Cloaths immediately. This business gives me double satisfaction. Pardon me, dear Sophia, for the mean mistrust I had of thee, and if this insolence go unrewarded, debar me of the blessing of thy Love; come Frank.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Gad a mercy Tom; now if this surly Country fellow should give this Beau a curst uncouth thrust in the Guts, 'twill disgrace his Shape most damnably. [Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Sir William, speaking as he comes.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Gads me, Tom, Tom, your Mistriss is in a swound there. Tom, Tom, what a Pox is he gone? the Devil, where is he gone? Horse, Horse there, Ounds, Murder, where is he gone? [shriek within, all the women run in.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: What's the matter Sir William, the matter?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Nothing at all Child; but where are they all gone?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, they took Coach, and drove away as fast as the Horses could lay Legs to ground.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: So! [Swounds.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Look to the Lady, carry her in. [Exeunt women.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: Ah me; and poor Mr. Spruce too gone?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: No, my dear, I am safe enough, but damnably frighted.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What, under the Table? The Devil haunt you; come out here, and run along with me to the Constable, and to my Lord Chief Justices, and the Kings Guards. Oh Lord, I shall have my Son Tom kill'd; kill my Son Frank no great matter, but my Son Tom kill'd would break my heart. Come along, you Cowardly, Sneaking.— Oh my Son Tom. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE the Fields.
div.stage: Enter Eldest Wealthy, and young Wealthy.

sp.speaker: E. Weal.
sp.p: BRother, your extraordinary Generosity has drawn you into a business, in which, of all Mankind you ought to have been the last I should have chosen; if I would have followed the barbarous custome of our Country, in making use of a Second, and under that abus'd phrase bring in a Friend, as if that were sit business to employ a real friend in: Therefore, Frank, however high your blood may work you, unless I am unequally oppos'd, draw not your Sword, but let me right my self.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p:
Faith Tom, I shall not much uphold that custome, but as you are a Brother and a Friend, a Stranger too, in all these Noble
Feats, I must exchange a Thrust or two to back you: besides, I sancy I am a Principal; for when these nice-chap't Grey-hounds hunt in couples, 'tis no single Booty that they aim at: My pretty one was mark't for Slaughter too. And Faith Sir, he shall win her e're he wear her, with your good leave.

sp.speaker: E. Weal.
sp.p: Make that appear, curse him that bars your hand: A Mistress is a glorious Cause to fight for. Pray Heavens the Villain be but brave enough to meet, and Rival me with equal fury, and not disgrace the beauty of my Cause.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Faith if he does he's strangely alter'd Sir: For I have heard of him in several Quarrels, where he would trust his Honour with a man that never yet gave him a good account of't: But such a Cause may work a Miracle. And mine I judge just such a noble person.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: I'm sorry for't: But certainly they'll come. And Brother, since you will be your own Master, I beg you be not rash, think what you do.

sp.speaker: Jun Weal.
sp.p: Faith Tom, and that's well thought on; so I will. Let me consider, I am going now to sight for my Mistriss: That is, She must be my Mistriss: Poor Soul, she knows nothing of the matter yet. And I am to Fight with a Gentleman, that for ought I know, knows nothing of the matter neither. Now I know I love her with all my heart, and perhaps against her will. And I'd fight for her with all my heart, but should she love me, that's against her will too: Then I'de marry her with all my Soul too. But pox on't, if she don't love me, that's against her will again; so the Lords will be done. I venture my Carkass upon an ill lay, there's an end on't. Brother, I have settled my Conscience; wou'd they wou'd come.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: However Fate designs you Frank, your Treasure must not be exhausted upon this account; there's Fifty Guineas, put them up safely, they'll prove good Friends, howe're the matter goes.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: What, Smart-money, Tom! Well, if I light upon a Surgeon that has any grace, a man may get a small Clap cur'd into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: You'll find if I should fall a hundred more in this Right Fob. Don't let those Rascals plunder me: For should they lay my Money out in Perriwigs and Cravat-strings 'twould grieve my Ghost worse than my Death. I have order'd Horses for us not far off. Damn 'um, the morning wastes, what mean these Loyterers; prethee look out.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Stand to your Arms Tom, your Enemy draws on.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Shamtown and Mr. Littlegad.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Sir, you're something late in doing your self Justice; unless you're sensible you deserv'd the blow I gave you. But this is no place for Parley. Draw.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: By your leave, but 'tis Dear Tom; a moments Temper. Sir, since these Gentlemen know what they fight for, 'twere something fit that you and I did too; for I suppose, if you dare own it, Sir, that you were charg'd with a damn'd white-powder'd Bullet-Deux, to have shot the other Lady, without any Report.

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: I scorn to disavow a passion, Sir, for beautiful Maria: But—

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: But your Servant Sir. Draw: Draw, both Traytors: Tom, fall on. They Fight.

lg.l: Thrust lower Tom, my Gentleman Dances. They fall, the two Brothers upon them.
St. George I'faith Tom. Your Sword, Sir.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal
sp.p: Your Life.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: I own it.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Your Sword Sir.

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: Take it. [Rises.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Then take it as my gift. Whene're I see you where this Quarrel arose, I'll take the forfeiture.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Art thou hurt Tom.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: No Frank, nor in danger of it.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: There Sir, your Sword again. The Lady's mine. Your Servant Gentlemen. You know on what conditions you live. Farewel. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Come let's be drest. Pox on the Ladies: We have done enough to talk of in the Coffee-house this month, and there's some comfort still. I'm glad 'tis over.

div.stage: Enter Sir William, Mr. Spruce, Guards, Constable and Watch.

sp.speaker: Mr. Spruce.
sp.p: Ha, who's here! 'tis they: One of them bleed.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Bloody too: Son Toms blood: Zounds Son Toms blood: Draw Dog, draw; where's my Son Tom, you Son of a Whore. Fall on, fall on.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: For Heavens sake, Gentlemen, he's just there; just yonder unhurt: just gave us both our lives.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Say you so: Hold them fast tho. Runs to the side of the Stage. So ho Tomme, Son Tomme. They move further.
My Dear Tomme. There's Frank: Was Frank hurt at all.

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No, Pox on him, he fights every day.
Ah, my dear Son Tom: [Runs and falls upon his Neck.
Here they come, here they come: Oh my dear Son Tommy. Ah my poor Tommy.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Good Sir, how came you hither with all this Rabble and Guards about you.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: 'Sdeath Brother, the Old fellow has seiz'd upon the Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you may go, we are sorry for this mistake.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ay, ay, you may go, and the Devil go with you.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: But good Sir, how came you hither?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: O Pox Tom, I could not sleep a wink— I have been at all the Slaughtering Fields I could name about the Town, at Barn-Elms, and at Putney-Common, and Chelsey-Fields, and Red-Lyon-Fields; at all the Golgatha's about the Town. And Mr. Spruce, I thank him, went along with me before it was quite Day; he's a damn'd Coward, but he's a very Honest Man.

sp.speaker: Mr. Spr.
sp.p: Indeed, Mr. Wealthy, my heart ak'd for you. And if my young Mr. Wealthy had been kill'd, 'twou'd have broke my Molly's Heart, she has such a tenderness for him.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Faith, he speaks true, I dare swear his heart ak'd, for he started at every Bush he came nigh; but I am glad to see thee my dear Tom and Frank; Frank's a good Boy too.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Sir, I thank you for your Tenderness, but would not for a thousand Worlds you had prevented us. Frank! Sir, this is your Son, my Brother and my Friend. I beg you would entertain him in your Heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Who, Frank? Frank's one' I always lov'd till he play'd the Rogue and Robb'd me. Frank, Frank, that was a filthy business: But no matter, I'm so o're-joy'd, I will give thee— let me see, what shall I give thee?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Ay, wou'd I cou'd see it.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I will give thee now, I will give thee. I will forgive thee now Frank; and there's a Gift for thee.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: That all: I thank you Sir, I thought to have paid you now.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What say'st thou Boy?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: I thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: O Tom, my joy to see thee has been so great, I forget to tell thee sad News; your Mistress Tom.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: What of her Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: O she's blind by this time.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: What mean you Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: She has cry'd her Eyes out Man. The little naughty Girl too, that never cry'd but just when she was born, has been shuffling ever since.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Now if that were for me, agad I'd cry too. No, no, it must be for me.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: I'll fly to comfort her, my dear Sophia.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Fly? Yes Tom you may fly; fly your Country if you please. Ounds, she swears she'll never see you more: You have betray'd her Honour, lost her Reputation, undone her quite, and fixt her in the Rank of loose-tail'd Ladies, whose good Name must be fought for, or be lost.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Cou'd she say this?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: More, more man; she'll go into the Country too night, but if you were kill'd, she swore she'd not out-live you.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: There's love and life in that: Curse on my Temper, what wrong could such a Dog have done to me? What Honour too to fight so poor a Creature? Did she not slight and scorn him to my face? O my Sophia, Pardon this last ill-natur'd Tempest here: Receive me with the Arms of Tenderness, and there becalm my Soul and thine for ever. Come, Sir Brother.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: I wait on you.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: There, there's Money for you; thank you Friends, thank you. My dear Tomme.

sp.speaker: Servants.
sp.p: Thank you Sir. Exeunt all but Mr. Spruce and Jun. Weal.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Well, I'll tell her what a kindness you have for her: And I'll assure you, Mr. Wealthy, there's no Love lost; I have heard her speak as kind things of you as of any body except me, and me you know—

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: O 'tis impossible she should love, that is love so far as to lye with any body but you.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Indeed Mr. Wealthy, I must say I believe I have been no small satisfaction to her since I marry'd her: she knows when she's well: I warrant you she wou'd not change me for any man. I won't keep you, Sir, I'll tell her how you love her.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: So do, Mr. Spruce: You need not fear Rivals.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Adieu.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Now for my Prize, I think I won her fairly. Exit.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Rival! ha, ha. No faith, I have not sold Perfumes, Ribbonds, Gloves, White-washes, and other sorts so long, but I know how to make my self agreeable as well as any of my Customers: Nor have I follow'd Tunbridge and Epsom, and sometimes Islington Wells so long, but that I know how to gain more hearts, as well as secure a perfect inclination, even I believe to the loathing of any other person. Therefore, when I am perswaded, like my Friend Topknot, into that ridiculous Opinion of being a Cuckold; the Lord have mercy upon my Head, my Wits are far gone indeed. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: We have a sad distracted House: All our Servants are run after Sir William; all the Maids are crying o're their Mistriss.— I pity poor Sophia, but that young Devil, however she seems mov'd with her Cousins grief, mourns her fear'd loss of my perfidious Wretch. They must be gone to fight, wou'd he were kill'd.— I had rather see him dead than see him hers. She knows I love him, I'm sure she must; and by that Letter try'd me unprovided; knows that I met him there, but I'll watch her, and try her to the quick: Betty.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: I charge you when Sir William returns, call me immediately; let me first see him on your life; take heed be not from the way. I know the Old fool loves her, he told me so himself, and ask'd my judgment, as being a Grave Person fit to advise. I'll tell him how she dotes upon his Son, and if he's suffer'd here he must not hope. And to convince him more, however the business goes, he shall report him dead, to try her, and if she stands that test, she does out-wit me. At least, Sir William's Jealousie I know will soon forbid the Rebrobate his House. And 'tis some pleasure to remove the Scene, and not be Nos'd by a Girl in my own House.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: O Madam, Madam, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: What ails my Woman's Heart, sure I can't pitty him. Well, what News?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Sir William and his two Sons are below: I am sure by Sir William's talk, they have been fighting, but neither of them seem hurt.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Away, I'll meet with him. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Discovers Mrs. Sophia and Mrs. Maria in Tears, their Maids waiting on them; one comes in.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: No Answer yet? No News?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: None Madam.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Is not Sir William come neither,' sure 'tis almost Noon. They must have fought, and the dear rash Man's kill'd. O Grief, O Insupportable Misfortune. Is't not enough my Reputation's stain'd, my Honour question'd, my Fame, that stood as fair as Day disputed, but must my Love dye in so ill a Cause? Was't not enough I swore to quit him ever, punish his Faults with everlasting absence, but must he dye, dye, upon my Account? Dye in my Quarrel?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Patience, dear Cousin, Patience, we shall hear better News than Death; I hope they're both together wheresoe're they are; Brothers, and Valiant both, ne're doubt their safety, those fellows dare not look them in the Face.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Is't not still worse, ingage a Family at once? Nay, I've wrong'd thee Maria, for though his Brother has been counted loose, he looks a Noble Gentleman; and now perhaps I have robb'd thee of thy choice.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Indeed, I shou'd be loath to hear his Death, though he is a perfect Stranger yet to me; but would I had never seen him, I know not what I feel; fear of the Widdow, fear of losing him, has made me love too soon, before I know whether he has the least good thought of me.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Madam, I hear some body:

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Run to the Door immediately; see who 'tis.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Sir William Madam, and the Widdow.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: She weeps; oh speak, Sir William speak, where's your Sons?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Sons? Son Tom's very well, but there has been the Devil to do; I have been forty mile about to find them, though Tom, he'll be with you presently.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But where's that other Son, Sir William? My heart akes.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Who, Frank?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Who Pop he was always Disobedient; there never comes better of Disobedience.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He's Dead, and I could tear her Eyes out for crying; I'll weep it all my self.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: What mean you Sir, he is not kill'd?

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: So Sir William told me; Mark, Mark, Sir William, a fresh Flood.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Then as I hope ever to dye in Peace, I'll never see or Wed to Mr. Wealthy.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: So, so, Widdow, there's fine work— How shall we get off this business?

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Have Patience, time enough.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Not see him Child, he's just at the Door almost, how could he help it, he loves thee Child, and is sorry he has angred you. [Exit Soph.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Whether is she going? Zounds, here will be more mischief. But how now little Eyes, what makes you cry? Look up.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Look up and Curse such a remorsless Father. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Now Sir be judge, is't fit that he stay here? if he goes, you yet might hope to win upon her.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No, no, stay, Pox on him, I'll send him packing: But here comes Tom. [Enter Tom.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: What News Sir? How does my angry Love? Have you inform'd her all? Will she forgive?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Yes: I told her thou wert well. But on her Knees, she vow'd she'd never see you; have but a little patience she'll forget it.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Which way went she?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: She's lock'd her self into that Room within; but where's your Brother?

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: I left him in the Garden; he's a coming.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, he'll meet Maria; I'll go watch them.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Run, run, he follows you. [Exit. Manet, Eld. Weal. and Sir Will.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Take Heart Tom, take Heart, I warrant we bring matters about again, have but patience. Pox on this young Dog, he's met her and spoil'd all the Plot. To her Tom, to her; beg her Pardon, and all will be well. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.l: Yes, on my knees. Nay, and she must forgive me.
For tho' the humblest way my Love will choose,
And all the Arts to tempt good Nature use,
Shou'd she at last my Penitence refuse.
I know my stubborn Temper will return,
And then too late she will her anger Mourn;
When I have seiz'd the Rascal Author of my Pain,
Kill'd, Stab'd, Destroy'd, and ruin'd all again.

div.head: SCENE discovers Maria on a Bank, in Tears.

sp.speaker: Jun. Well.
sp.p: A Pritty Garden this; ha, whose that, the purchase of my Sword? My Love in Tears? Mistrust of my Sickness! I'll Court her in Heroicks. So, when the God of War sets out for Fights and Ranges through the Fields in Blood and Dust, the sweet-ey'd Venus takes a lonely flight, and in some soft Retirement of Heaven, bemoans the vast Fatigues the Hero bears. So, so, this will do in Tears. My Goddess.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Bless me!

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, I han't wash'd my face to Day, and she takes me for Vulcan. Mars, by the Gods, come flusht with Honour from the Bloody Field, ready to lay them all beneath your seet.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Alive!

sp.speaker: Jun. Well.
sp.p: Yes, live to tell you how I fought; to tell you how I'd dye for my Delight, so that you'd let me tast this lovely Fruit, and make live again. [Kiss.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: By Heaven no Ghost; true solid Flesh and Blood.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Such as it is Madam; 'tis blood that flutters now about my Heart, and Dances to the Musick of your Eyes. Oh, Fair one, since I saw you Fate has been abroad, and angry Rivals threatned in the Fields, yet nought cou'd take that Object from my mind.

lg.l: I kept your lovely form still in my view,
And as I fought, I look'd, and fought for you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Twas frankly fought; and Sir, I give welcome from your Wars, but grieve I cannot recompence your Valour.

lg.l: A Heart's a trifle to so great a Hero,
And that is all we Virgins can bestow.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: That and a little more is all I ask, and Virgins have them both.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But sure you would not rob me of my All, my most Uncourteous Knight?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p:
No, I'd be thy All, thy All in All; thy All in ev'ry part.
And you shall have all me with all my heart. And know now I've begun, I'll fight Mankind to keep thee to my self.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Whether I give incouragement or no?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: I'll win you as a Hero should his Mistriss, kill Monsters, Dragons, do Herculean Labours; I hate a snivling, tedious, seven years Courtship, losing our Youth and time: Put me to Action, let me convince you early of my Love, that I may neither lose my time nor you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: For a small Tryal; answer me quick; tell me. Know I the Lady which you went to meet in the Exchange. Do you boggle? Good b'y Sir.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: 'Tis a Rascally Trick; but in short, it was my Lady Sly, and there's quirk for your quirk. Now, Madam, will you stand me a question?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: What made your Ladiship in Tears just now?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'll give you leave to guess it was for you.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: And give me leave thus then to pay my thanks, since I have own'd this early kindness for you; you must expect i'll be convinc'd of yours.

lg.l: Therefore prepare, and as I find
You constant, I'll be kind.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Rogue, Dog, Traytor; I'll fight with him my self.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: I shall be turned out of Doors, and lose my opportunities with my dear one; gad, I've a Trick left for that still.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Draw Rival draw, I—

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Good Dad put up, O Se Defendendo's a Damn'd business.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why look you now! The Rogue would murder me; I'll swear the Peace against him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Are you mad Sir William? Nay then fight it out.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Sir William, hear me.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Hear you? No you Dog, but I'll hang you.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Then Sir I resign my self to you, will you yet hear me?

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: What's the matter, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Only Sir William is bewitch'd. I'll watch him if he turns him out of Doors, I have a Game to play, for I must plague him; and if I find he loves me, let him take me. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Good Sir, what is't that disorders you?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What's that to you Sir; and now I think on't, you advised me to it; you were the Match-maker.

sp.speaker: Jan. Weal.
sp.p: Sir you mistake, why wont you hear me?

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, you undo my Brother; he has no thoughts of Maria.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What made him with her then?

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Meer accident; he's promis'd to the Widdow, Sir, to my knowledge, tho' she will not own it.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: How! she's Rich; she's a Miserable Woman then: The Dog will undo her. Come hither Sirrah, do you make love to the Widdow here?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Sir, here are Letters under her Hand, that would have convinc'd you as much, would you have been patient; yet should she ever know I own'd it Sir, 'twou'd break the Match, and ruin my Designs.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: This may be true, the Widdow's Jealous of him with Maria; so much the better, 'twill make her earnester in my Affair. Well Sir, if she be fool enough, go on, I'll keep your Counsel. [Exit Sir William.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Faith Tom, thou cam'st in a lucky hour, we were just a going to take a fair Tilt, the old Gentlemans Jealousie was up; how fairs your Mistriss? When is your happy day?

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: She utterly at first deny'd me seeing her, and so Resents the Rashness of my Quarrel, such an Affront done to her Reputation, by Heav'n, I fear'd she'd never pardon it. But so far I have prosper'd, only pardon'd.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: That's all the effect of love; a day or two will soften her again, write to her first; Maria will attend and plead thy cause.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: How goes the Cause with her?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: It thrives; she gives me a free Stage, and if I can convince her of my Love, which must be done, she gives me reasonable hopes of hers, but swears she'll try me first.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Success to you in all: My task is hard, but I'll about it.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Never fear Tom; she's born to be thy Wife: And as sure

lg.l: As after Marriage they must all be Rul'd,
So Tom, before it they may all be Fool'd. Exeunt severally.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: A Comfortable Being this! Snapp'd last Night like a Dog by a parcel of Rascally Bailiffs, and Mew'd up here for 500 l. Lost my Mistriss, lost my Liberty, lost my Widdow too, I fear, for I can get no answer of my Letter. The Devil! This must be malice: I owe 500 l. but to no one, and how the Devil they should all agree to confound me, I can't tell. Enter Eld. Wealthy.
Tom, this is kind indeed, to visit a Brother in affliction.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Dear Frank, I come to beg thou'lt let me know which is the best and readiest way to serve you? What's the Action?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Five hundred Pound. I owe the Town indeed 500 l. and I believe the whole Town is the Plaintiff: Therefore the readiest way, dear Tom, will be to search the Offices, that I may know at whose suit I am here; my Father knows of it, I guess he's strangely troubled.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Strangely indeed, for he wou'd let thee starve; but I'll away and search the Offices.— Be not dejected Frank, for shortly I shall have command of Money, and if no way but paying of the Debt will give you freedom, I'll lay down the Money, and thou shalt laugh at the Old Man's ill Nature.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Does Maria know it?

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Yes, and pitties you extreamly, rails at my Father for his Cruelty, and speaks most tenderly of your Misfortune.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: There's some comfort still; if I can get out no other way, tell her I'll break through the Stone Walls to thank her.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Never fear, I'll bring you News immediately. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: I wonder how this Old Rogue my Father, could get two such honest fellows for his Sons; this is a Brother. But wou'd my Widdow wou'd come, she's Rich, and I'm engag'd to her already, an't 'twou'd be even a pain to be oblig'd so much by one who is to me a stranger, though my Brother. How like a Counter-Rat I look.— I'll lay me down to sleep, and dream of Liberty.
My dear Widdow! This is kind indeed.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Good Sir, why did you send for me?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: For the same Reason which I hope you came. Why all this Coldness? What have you learnt this lesson of my Father, and come to preach, or practise it upon me? My Constancy and Love's but ill repaid, if this must be the time you chuse for parting.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Constancy! Thou Devil!

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: In Hell, Madam, you might have said, but no Devil.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Yes Devil, to wrong the woman, that ne'r yet wrong'd you, but sacrific'd my Fortunes and my Honour to make you easie, and maintain your Pride.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Did I e're yet disown it, Madam?

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Most basely in your Actions, though your Words (that natural deceit in all your Sex) flatter'd me still to keep me still your Fool; but I'm convinc'd; and now 'tis all the pleasure I have left, that I came here in scorn, to let you know I've seen your baseness punish'd. So farewell. Offers to go.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Madam, though I can meet your scorn with scorn, and Perish as indifferently as you wish it, you shall in Justice let me know what grounds for this; or is it a Pretence? Own it true Woman, own it, find out a Lustier Fellow for your use, you've nick'd your time; laugh at your Quondam Servant, and be Damn'd.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: This wo'not do, your Pride won't carry't off, or make me think of you in any terms, but as the most ungrateful of Mankind.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: For what? 'Sdeath, how? Be plain.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: You cannot guess: O Impudence!

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: You Scold well, indeed Madam; but I remember a bit of a Song very proper; I'll Sing it if you please, Madam.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Sing! The Devil choak him.
sp.stage:
He Sings.
Love and true Merit do seldom prevail.
For always you hold a wet Eel by the Tail.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Good Mr. True Merit; thou Monster, look upon this Letter, you don't know it, though the hand be Counterfeit; a shallow Cheat.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.l: Then Witness for me all you Powers Divine,
If this be any Word, or Hand of mine.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: O Impudence!

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Perdition seize me if I ever saw it.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Monstrous!

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: If I did Madam, may I never be bless'd with the Light of the Sun.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Curs'd Lye.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: But be shut up in Eternal Darkness in this Dungeon.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Unparellell'd Villany!

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: May I be Rooted here a Spectacle to your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Woud'st thou go to the Devil directly?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Nor be ever more in your good Grace.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Be Hang'd.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: If I know one word of the matter; therefore, good Madam, tell me how you came by this.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: You did not write this to Mrs. Maria?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Why, did she give it you?

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: What's that to you: By Heaven! I ne're thought of this: Upon my Soul it was a Trick; but by his haste to know I find his Thoughts, yet he is better than I thought of him, and I must use him better.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: 'Twas my pretty little Rogues Letter; dull Dog, she's Jealous of me. Ah, wou'd I were out.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Shall I believe you did not write this Letter?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Shall I curse any more?

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: How came you by it?

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: 'Twas sent me as a Copy stole from you of one you, writ.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: A likely Story; and you soon believ'd it, to shake me off, just now starving in Goal; I thank you Madam.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: No, my dear Wealthy, never, wou'd you love me.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Cou'd I have spoke such barbarous things to you?

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: No, but you'd do worse shou'd you ever leave me.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Leave you, Child! I can neither leave you, nor be with you while I am here.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: What is your Debt?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Only five hundred Pound.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: A good round Summ! By times he'll certainly have all I have; I'll break a right Widdows Rule for once, and Marry him, he has osten proffer'd at it. Mr. Wealthy, the Summ's no Trifle to the best Estate; you have oft propos'd, take me and all I have, i'll give you Liberty to Night.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p:
I must lye to get out; agreed— but in the mean time, my
dear, 'tis no Novelty to you and I, we'll Seal this business in the other Room.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Fye, Mr. Wealthy, not till I'm all your own.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: She's been all my own these two years. Nay, Childish, why so unwilling?

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Lord! What do you mean? Fye, in a Prison?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: In a Palace Child, with good Company; the place indeed is homely, but the Entertainment shall be the heartier. Nay, come.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Lord, I'll swear there is no dealing with you. [Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Maria in Boys Cloaths, and the Gaoler.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How bears the Gentleman his Confinement Gaoler?

sp.speaker: Goal.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You know by the Bailiffs on what account he is here, they told you, I suppose; there's Money for you, when I release him ask him for no Fees, he must go with me. There's no Company with him, is there?

sp.speaker: Goal.
sp.p: Yes, a Lady.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What, in the inner Room? Run, run, run in immediately, tell him a Gentleman would speak with him: No, stay, here he comes— how like a Rogue he looks.

div.stage: Re-enter young Wealthy and the Widdow.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Madam, your Servant, you'll not forget; adieu. [Exit. Widdow.
I have seen this Youth somewhere; Sir, would you speak with me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I come from the Gentleman my Brother, you fought with t'other day, upon a Ladies account.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am to tell you 'tis in his Power, and only his, to take this Action off, and give you Inlargement.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: In his?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Wonder not Sir; you are Rivals, and he took this way, this surer than his Sword, to Ruine you. He had a Catalogue of all your Debts, and from each Creditor, whom he has paid, full force to lay his Action, which he'll take off upon no other Terms than a perfect Resignation of your Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Child, you may go, I'll bring my Answers back my self, and tell him next time I have his Sword, I'll spoil his neat Proposals. Go, Lad, go.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But Sir, she loves him.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Therefore I'll cut his Throat.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: She'll hate and curse you for't.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Not when he's dead Child, she may like me then.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But how will you get out Sir?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: What's that to thee Impertinence; prithee go tell thy Brother, I'd Perish if I were within his Power, rather than yield him up a thought of her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But why are you so stubborn, when to my Face I see you were ingag'd to cross his just desires?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Why, how now Child, though that pretty face does plead for thee, be gone, or I shall use the scurvily.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You'll not Resign her then?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: I'll rip his heart, thine and my own too, up first: therefore be gone.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Then Sir, to shew he does as much deserve her as your self, I have Orders here to give you Liberty; if you dare meet him behind Southampton-House, within this half hour alone, where he declares no Quarter must be given, but one of you must dye upon the Spot.
sp.stage: [Takes his Sword from the Gaoler, gives him his Sword.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Sir, this obligation's great, and i'll return it to your Brothers heart.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Guard your own Sir— If you please— [Points to the door.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Sans Ceremony, faith Sir; from a Prison. [Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Shamtown, with a black Scarf at one Door, and Mr. Littlegad at the other.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Mr. Littlegad, my Friend and Champion, how do you?

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: Wholly Devoted still to Mr. Shamtown, and if there be no dangerous Deaths Wound lyes beneath that Noble Escutheon of your Honour, I wish you Joy of such a Manly mark; and by my faith, I could have wish'd the like to have signaliz'd my self. You are for the Coffee-house no doubt, I'm sorry I am engag'd: The first surprizes, the many questions, how, when, and with whom, where; at Southampton-house.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: With this short Sword.

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: And how bravely t'other fought you too; be sure mark that, that adds to you, you know; then you disarm'd him.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Accident in fight, where the brave draw their Swords, the Combat's doubtful.

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: If they ask who were Seconds?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Fester my Wound Sir, if I do you wrong; will you go with me?

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: Damn it, how Love and Honour wrack my mind: Why for a Woman should I rob my self of all I fought for? Pox of Visiting, and yet I must. Said each, there's no danger now to second you, and yet there's real Honour to be got. But early in the morning I'll be there; farewel Sir.

lg.l: I envy you the Honour you must meet,
But go to lay mine at my Coelia's feet. [Exeunt severally.

div.head: SCENE the Fields.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Not come yet? this is the place; surely this Villain does design to Murder me, or else fought booty with me the last time. No Seconds to so furious a Challenge; I shall have my Throat Cut here in the Woods, and be Buried, like the Children in the Ballad, by the Robin Red-breasts.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, your Servant, you're as good as your word.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: That's more than your Brother dare; why is he not here? And why are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, the hurt he receiv'd in his Arm, has unexpectedly disabled him, but he has sent his Sword by me.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Give it me Child; indeed I should have took it had he come.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What mean you Sir? I came to do him Justice, maintain his Merit, is to be preferr'd to yours.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, does he take my Mistriss for a Prize for Boys to Box for?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Boys Sir? Draw.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Flout not Sir, we'll try who is the strongest.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Ay, this is something, you young White-liver'd Dog.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Will you resign your Mistriss, or dye upon the Spot?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Not till I've ript thy little Guts up. Fight me but one by one.

sp.speaker: The 1st.
sp.p: No, thank you Sir, we can Murder you a better way.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Speak, or we strike.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Hold.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Stand this, and take me quick.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Smooth-face stand off, though thou'rt the very'st Rascal I e're saw, methinks I'd save thy Life to tell my Story. Thou'st such a lying, wheedling face, thou canst not fail to work upon a Woman, when at this time methinks I could forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I speak for you.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Yes, tell her how I fought, or if I perish, tell her how I fell; tell her how much beyond my life I lov'd her, without the least security of hers. The Name, the Pride, the Honour of my Love, thou shalt in softning Eloquence relate; and though thou art a very Villain, look as thou dost speak as thou wou'dst for him, and win her to my Bed, or to my Grave.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I must try him further yet, though my heart akes with love and tenderness. Am I so much oblig'd to Nature, Sir? Look then, despair and dye: 'Twas my own Jealousie that drew me here, the other was a meer Pretension. I love Maria too above my life, and therefore dare not, at an equal hazard, expose my life. I follow'd her to Town, abandoning my Family and Friends: Mad with my Love, and Resolute to win her. Tho' for your Generosity, which thus far in a Rival I can pitty, since you believe I cou'd prevail for you, with looking, speaking, flattering, any thing. You cannot doubt the Conqnest, for my self, yet still Renounce her and I'll spare thy life.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: I'll not return that Complement to you, there is no safety if I let you live; therefore prepare, and if thou hast one grain of Honour left, venture me one fair thrust among the Crowd, and I'll forgive thee yet.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Hold, for i'll Rival you in Honour too. Be gone, there's your Reward. You'll bate the Murder. I'll thrust my single Arm in such a Cause, and dye or else deserve her. [The two Ruffians go off.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Dye or deserve her; 'Sdeath, thou'lt win her from me. Prithee contrive some way we may be friends, I wou'd not nip such Honour in the bud; thou art too young to think of Marrying— Gad thou shalt be her Page: I'll give thee leave to own thy Passion, Ogle thy Heart out, tell her pritty Tales, she'll listen to the Musick of thy Voice, and give thee sigh for sigh. Put up thy Sword, 'Sdeath thou holds it like a Girl.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: By Heaven! and look'st like one— Where were my Eyes?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pox on your Eyes Sir: Damme, will you fight?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Yes, Damme, thus, thus, and thus.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now where's that cruel Creature upon Earth, that cou'd deny so Generous a Lover?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: If there be such, she lives among the Bears, and never came in Christian Company. She never said her Prayers, sigh'd, shed a Tear, or play'd with Boys, or Babys, in her Life.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Then I am won.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: By Heav'n, and fairly too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What will you do with me now?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: E'ne Marry thee, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And beat me?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: No, live and dye with thee, by Jove. Put up thy Sword, and trust thy Eyes alone.

lg.l: To those bright Planets, I my Trophies yield;
By them thou'rt always Mistriss of the Field.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Spruce and his Wife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: Nay, but you shall my dear, or I'll swear I wont let you go.

sp.speaker: Mr. Spr.
sp.p: Indeed Molly but I wont; I must go Child, there's no body at the Shop this Morning.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: Nay, but consider he's your Friend, a fine young Gentleman, and one you love:

sp.speaker: Mr. Spr.
sp.p: Very well; Madam, and what am I?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: Oh, thou art the sweetest Creature Living, but you don't love me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Spr.
sp.p: Yes, Molly, but I do, and my self too; and therefore, tho' I love Mr. Wealthy as well as you do, I'll be bound for no body.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: Then I'm sure you don't love him half so well as I do, for I'd be bound Body for Body for him. Poor Gentleman, so I wou'd; but you don't love him because I do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Spr.
sp.p: Not if you love him better than me, Molly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: Yes, yes, very likely, as if I did not know when I was well; but you know how handsom you are, and that makes you as Proud as the Devil. This is like all the rest, your running to Epsom and Tunbridge; so it is.

sp.speaker: Mr. Spr.
sp.p: Poor Rogue, now I have vext her. Why, my dear, I always take you with me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: Yes, yes, to show me I don't deserve you, to see a hundred Women Dancing after you, and pulling you as if they'd eat you from me.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Poor Fool, nay, I must confess they do reaze me: But how can I help all this, Molly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spruce.
sp.p: You might stay at home, like an honest man: Wou'd I had married the ugliest fellow in England, then I might have had him to my self; or at least I might have rhelish'd another after him; but to be Marry'd as I am; I shall be poyson'd one of these days, and then you'll be rid of me.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Nay, prethee Molly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spruce.
sp.p: Don't I see it; han't we a hundred Ladies for one Gentleman, that comes to our Shop?

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Gad, and that's true, and I never minded it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spruce.
sp.p: Lord Mistress you're the happiest Woman, says one; you must certainly have delicate Children, says another; pray how long have you been Married, says a third.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Womens talk Child: prethee Molly, I love thee, let 'em say what they will.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spruce.
sp.p: Yes, I know 'tis Womens talk: Lord, says another, that can never be his own Hair: Bless me, he has delicate Teeth; how strangely that French's Beard becomes some sort of Faces: Nay more, I'll swear, I've heard them say they believed you were Painted, you had such a delicate Complexion.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Nay, prithee Molly, you make me smile; for the Devil take me, if I han't been told the same a thousand times.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: Have you so? Very well, who should I love better than you then? And but that you have a mind to be cross, I have heard you say a thousand times, you would do any thing to serve Mr. Wealthy, and yet refuse me to bail him out of Prison only for five hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: I tell thee Moll, I forswore it when I was Apprentice, or I vow thou woud'st tempt me to Ruine my self; his Father and Brother will take care of him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spruce.
sp.p: But they must not know it; and I'm sure if they do, we shall so oblige that Family, we shall get thrice as much by it.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Gad Molly do not tempt me; I love you so, I shall play the Fool, i'll run away from you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: I'll swear i'll follow you to the Change.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Wife keep the House, remember your Lord commands you; I must be gone. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p:
And i'll be with you, for my dear Wealthy must be freed to Night; 'tis a great blessing to know a Husbands blind side; what a
good humour he's run away with for my praising his Beauty. Bless me! how unreasonably we are accus'd for Cuckolding our Husbands, when certainly, either by Vanity, Folly, Pride, or ill Nature, they draw it upon themselves, and yet they have the impudence to believe we must love all these faults, honour all these faults, and obey all these faults, that obeys the Devil, and yet without this, we are the Vipers that defile your Beds, Plant Hieroglyphick Figures on their Heads, when alas,

lg.l: No Woman does her Lawful Prince dethrone,
But you're so Proud you will so Rule alone;
We must be Slaves, or Cuckold ev'ry one.
If therefore you will not this Crime repent,
And we must still obey your Government,
Exalted be your Horns, by my Consent. Exit.

div.head: SOPHIA alone.
div.stage: Enter Elder Wealthy; she is going off.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, stay and hear me first; why so unjust? Will you not let me plead in such a Cause, where Love and Life, my Heaven to come, and here, which all's at stake?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: What wou'd you Plead for, Sir? Have I not pardon'd you at the first word? Even in the midst of Tears, believing your offence the effect of Love? And yet you will not grant me one Request.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Not grant it: What Madam?

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Me to my self; you grudge me sure my Grief, or else have very little of your own, that can at this time covet Company.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.l: Why, Madam, am I your aversion grown?
So alter'd in a day! What have I done?
sp.p: That Tears and Pray'rs, Pity and Love in you, (which once I did expect) cannot wipe off▪

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Bless me! that you can ask what you have done: Are you as Merciless as your Father, Sir? Pray give me way, you'd make me hate you, to see you Master of no more Compassion; pray give me way.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Not till you're torn from me. Dear Madam, do but hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: No, you've already made me break my Oath, which was so strict, never to have seen you more; I must be gone.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Dear Tom; what, flying of him, Madam?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Alive! Blest be my Eyes, blest be the day, and be for ever blest thou best of Men.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: What means this Extasie?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Thy Father told me he was kill'd.; kill'd in thy Quarrel, upon my account. Or think you I cou'd e're have parted with you, but Tears of Joy flow on so fast upon me, I cannot speak the fulness of my Soul.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: By Heaven, nor I, but thus.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My dear Cousin, let me but recover the fright you put me in. Dear Cousin and Sir, I beg your Pardons, for indeed I might have prevented this mistake, but that my head ran too much upon this Gentleman; for in short, the Report of it at first, was a Plot of the Old Fool your Father, Sir, and that Exquisite Hypocrite my Lady Sly: For as I went down into the Garden, as he has the Impudence since to believe, to lament his loss, I met this living thing there, who has since, upon some small tryals of his Faith, own'd his Intrigue with the Widdow, confess'd himself a Rogue, and I have forgiven him.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Surely, your Ladiship wou'd summ up an Evidence well: But Madam, shou'd I begin the Story, which shortly you will hear, how like a Rogue she has us'd me, how like a Gaol-Bird she has treated me, and all, as she terms it, for a small tryal of my Faith. You wou'd wonder how I cou'd ever forgive her, yet, like a good natur'd fool, I have done it, and she has the Grace to thank me for't.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: And must we wish you Joy, Frank? You play sure.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Faith, Tom, I'm in a Whimsical Dilemma, for I have oft forswore the Marriage-knot, and yet it is some way we must be joyn'd, for we have made an Oath we'll never part.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis a sad Truth; but yet Mr. Wealthy, who knows, a good Example may prevail upon the Churl.

sp.speaker: Jun Weal.
sp.p: Say you so? Then Tom, I Challenge you; first, to joyn with us in a Plot we have laid, for the two Fools, my Father and the Widdow; next, you must meet no Denials. Now, Madam, with your fair Lady in your hand to morrow, at the dread hour which we call Canonical. Whereas you came into the World before me, so quit it, Sir; dye to your Lady first, and though my heart akes even to think upon it, since this young Niggard will be paid her price before she parts with any of her Goods, let the black fellow thunder in my Ears.

lg.l: For thee such wounding Words I will indure,
No Surgeon (Child) on Earth can ever cure.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: I take your silence for consent, my dear; and Frank i'll meet you; as to your Plot, we leave it wholly to you, act as you please, and we'll obey your Orders; here comes the Widdow, Frank.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Be gone every one.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What, must I trust you with her?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Go, go, you Fool, I must make love a little to help the Plot; mind yours too with my Father.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'll to Sir William for my part, and be with you in a minute.

div.stage: Exit all but young Wealthy. Enter to him the Widdow.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: My dear Wealthy at Liberty, and here; what can this mean?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Two Miracles, my dear.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: As how, my Love?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: My Delivery and my Constancy; i'll swear I was deliver'd by Miracle; and for my Constancy, you may judge of that, who rail'd against me so lately without Reason. But Widdow, thy Generosity has so prevail'd upon me, and so much I esteem you my Deliverer:

lg.l: I come my new-born Freedom to resign,
And make you Matrimonially mine.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: No, Mr. Wealthy, though I own your kindnesses, on second thoughts I dare not be so rash.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Why, how now Widdow, what repent your bargain?

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Only for fear you shou'd.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Ridiculous!

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Ah Wealthy, thou'rt too much a Libertine to use a Woman well thou hast enjoy'd; Maria, that untainted fruit, may please. A Marriage-Bed requires a Maiden-head.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Why Widdow, dost thou think i'll be a Cuckold, at least, to any Man but to my self? Marry a Girl! No, faith Madam, I leave her to Sir William, and but that thou art an Infidel, I could tell thee such a Story of my Constancy, such a Tryal of my Faith, such a Miraculous Preservation of thy Honour, that wou'd I were choak'd if I thought I had been half so honest; you saw that young Gentleman that came to speak with me just as we parted.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Yes, what then?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Only he dogg'd you thither.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Me, by whose Orders?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p:
He said he was the Brother of my Rival; and that unless
I wou'd resign Maria, I shou'd lye there and rot, but if I wou'd, he had orders to release me.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: On this I begg'd he'd show me to the door, Maria might be his Wife with all my heart; the Lady that he saw was my first choice, and for her sake, no threatning of his Brother, I did accept my freedome at his hands.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: I own 'twas more than I can e're deserve. But why dog me, did he take me for her?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: No Child, but I took her for him.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Her sor him! Bless me, Sir, what mean you?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Maria, by the Gods, that Devil her self, was sole contriver of that hellish Plot; in that disguise discover'd our intrigues, own'd some small kindness formerly for me, bid me repent my folly, and my loss, swore that to morrow morning she'd be Married, and ruine me for ever with my Father; then with a Curse she wish'd me Joy with you, and bid me hug my Monumental Widdow.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: A Curse for her again. But my Dear Wealthy:

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: My dear Widdow.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: How can I requite you?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: We'll be married to Night.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Impossible!

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Then with my Brother Tom, in your private little Chappel, at the end of the Hall, by six in the Morning; by Heav'n I'll stay no longer. Here comes my Father and she with him, i'm sure this Match must please him, and i'll scorn her: Besides, I have already laid a Scene of mirth, which you must joyn in; Shamtown and Littlegad shall pay the Fiddlers; the Old Fool hates them, and will joyn in it. Be gone, i'll meet you presently i'th' Garden, and then inform you all.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Adieu, my dear. [Exit Widdow.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: She smiles and winks, it thrives; Gads so, the Old fellow Dances as he goes: Yes, yes, you shall be married.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Who's that? Why, Sirrah, who are you? Why, how now Frank, and my Boy Frank: And a Franky, Franky, Franky, Frank; Sirrah, down on your knees.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Down on your knees, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: And a Franky, Franky, &c.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: What the Devil ails the Old Fellow?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Sirrah, you are to be Married, I hear.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: To whom, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: To the discreet Lady of the House.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: To the discreet Lady of the House; i'm glad on't you Dog.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and beg your blessing in't.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Yes, Sirrah, I have blest you Sirrah; rise up and say i've set you upon your Legs, Sirrah. I have, given you three hundred a year, Sirrah. Franky, you Dog, and a Franky, Franky, &c.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Sir, I thank you, and am doubly oblig'd that you are so over joy'd at my good Fortune.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No, Sirrah, not altogether so neither, I have Joy of my own too, and Joy for other people, as time shall try, as old as I am: Sirrah, there's your Mother-in-law.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Possible!

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ay, you Dog, it e'nt impossible, is it?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No, Sir? What then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, I wish you Joy, I was just going to ask the Lady Blessing.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No, Sir, you shant ask her Blessing, she shall have enow of her own to ask her Blessing, Sirrah; I will get upon her Body such a parcel of Gray-headed Cupids, it shall be the Worlds Wonder.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, faith, Sir William, we'll do our best, for since Mr. Wealthy is ingag'd to the Widdow, and his Brother to my Cousin, I swear I will not be out of the Family; and let me alone to make you young again.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why, Sirrah, why do'nt you rejoyce to see your Old Dad so happy.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Sir, I do so much rejoyce, that if the Lady will be rul'd by me, we'll make this the Merriest pair Royal of Weddings, as e're were heard of.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: As how, dear Mr. Wealthy; if there be any mischief in it, I am for you.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p:
I must own, Madam, I have an implacable malice to the two Fools, that occasioned the mistake between Tom and his Mistriss. I have prevail'd with my Sister that shall be, who has writ a Note inviting them hither in a disguise; Mr. Shamtown, who expects to carry off the Prize, to morrow morning, no less than to be Married
here, even in this House: And Madam, if you'd joyn, and write to Mr. Littlegad as I told you.—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: We'll toss 'em in a Blanket, Fops, Fools.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Agreed, I write this minute. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Go, go, you Rogue: I shall so tickle you: Sirrah, am not I a lucky old Toad: But you don't rejoyce, Pox on you don't rejoyce at your Fathers fortune. Pish you an't over-joy'd, for my own part Frank, it comes upon me so of a sudden, I have such a preturbation of Spirit, and such a consternation of joy, on my conscience, I can hardly tell where I am.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Upon my life, if the surprize be so great, you had best let blood.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No, thank you Sirrah, an old fellow to be Married to a a young Woman and let blood, wou'd I had as much as when I got your Brother Tom, then I wou'd so rumble her, and so tumble her, and so jumble her, and so fumble her Frank; and a Frank, &c. But Sirrah, I'll to my Daughter-in-law, and manage her to the last penny for you: She's a parlous Slut, and Franky, Frank, &c. Exit.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Not so very close, but now our Plot is sure, I'm satisfied our Letters took the effect;

lg.l: The Fools bit at it rarely as I hear,
And early shall be welcome to the snare. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Sir William and Maria with Lights, Young Wealthy meets 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Are they come, are the Fools come?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: 'Sdeath out with the Lights, they're just got into the little Chappel, their Ladies wait 'em impatiently; be sure Sir, you do not speak till you see 'em fast bound, and then—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ay, and then my little Eyes. The Lights are carry'd off.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Hist.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Your hand, your hand, I hear the Widdow; that's just where I appointed her. They steal off. Then enter the Widdow.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: So, I see the Unfortunate Lovers are come, my dear.

div.stage: Enter Shamtown like a Chair-man, and another.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Hist, they are at it: This is the Hall: This happy darkness doubles my Disguise. Friend, did you see any of the Family to day?

sp.speaker: Chair-man.
sp.p: No, Sir, but I saw a Chair go in about half an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Shamt.
sp.p:
Punctual Creature; for fear I should not bring one. In the Passage, from the surther corner of the Hall, we shall find that Chair, and in it the Treasure of my Soul, which we must carry off; such are
my kind directions; and then I think I have conquer'd you Mr. Wealthy. Follow me close, and now the coast is clear, be sure you mind the charge. This is the only secret I ever kept from Littlegad: ah would he were as happy. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; wish you joy, Gentlemen, wish you joy; you are met with I'faith; Lights there Lights: Now for me, my Dear, Pox of their hugger mugger work: we'll be married in state.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: The Devil, is this Sir William! that was just where Wealthy appointed me. You mistake Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Widdow, where's my little Devil? What ho?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Coming, coming Sir William (Within.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Gad they have it, Fops, Fools, Cuckolds, Rogues, didst thou see 'em? Enter Maria.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: See 'em! I think I provided well for my Maids.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Come, come, I'll Maid you: Where's Frank? why Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Sirrah, to your Wife, you ill-natur'd Dog, this was your contrivance. Where's Tom?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Just coming Sir, our turn's next: Where's this Parson; if he be not out of breath, he may do our work too.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Pox on him, and his sneaking bit of Wax Candle; I could hardly discern a Man from a Post; and the two Sluts stood with their backs to us.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: I swear Mr. Wealthy, you're an unmerciful man; I am sorry to see you have so much ill nature; what have you done with the poor Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: When they have serv'd our mirth a little further, we'll dispatch em with their Ladies. Pox where's this Parson, we'll fetch him by the Ears. Exit Sir William and Young Wealthy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I suppose, Madam, I need not wish your Ladyship Joy, since you have made choice of a young man so able to give it as Mr. Wealthy; for my part, I confess you may wonder at this Match, but upon my word, Madam, I am altogether satisfied with these poor Remains of Sir William, since he will put me in a way to return your many obligations upon your dear Mr. Wealthy.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: I understand her, but since Wealthy is mine, can laugh at her. aside.)

Your Ladiship is highly obliging, and though indeed, Madam, I may seem to have the better of you in this business, yet I cannot tell
how wild Mr: Wealthy may prove; and at least, you may live at quiet with Sir William, an old Gentleman that is tam'd to your hands.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now cou'd I fall out with her in earnest, for her impudence, though I am sure of my Man. aside.)
If I may be so bold, pray Madam, how long was handsome Mr. Wealthy an admirer of you, before he gain'd the mighty Conquest over you?

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: If Madam, without blushing I might tell you, I think too long. However, since to Night he must be mine, i'll reap that lost years Harvest in this Night; sure of my bliss, i'll seize my Vigorous Swain, free from the Curse of disappointing Age: Blind with my Love, give loose to my desires, and in continued Trances cheat the Night.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh, Impudence: By Heaven, she's lying with him to my face, I can hold no longer. aside.)
And is your Gravity come to this? Sure, Madam, you will not ravish Mr. Wealthy.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Sure, Madam, but I may, before Sir William can your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Poor cheated Fool.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Poor angry Girl.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, value your self upon your Age, Wealthy admires it, Madam; an Old Lady, and a Cast Widdow, must be Honourable.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, have you lost your longing, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Nay then, take the Reverse of all thy promis'd Joys, which in malicious eagerness you drest. On Wealthy's breast you'll find but poor support; upon thy buried Honour lean thy head; Bath in the tears shed for that satal loss; Curse my dear Wealthy's Eyes; cry out thy own. Blind with thy miseries, renounce the Day, and in eternal howlings waste the Night. By Heaven, thou art betray'd, Wealthy's my Husband; Married just now, before thy cheated Eyes. Poor fool, thou art a witness to the Match, and hall Contriver of thy own Destruction.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: So, so, the Rival Queens have been at it, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Speak Wealthy, e're my heart breaks with my wrongs: Have you betray'd me? Are you such a Villain?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Faith, Widdow, not to keep you in suspence, on second thoughts I could not be so rash; therefore to save your Reputation still, own you were in th' design, and laugh with us. Here comes the old Man and the Parson; now the Plot thick'ns, or the Devils in't.

div.stage: Enter Sir William and the Parson.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Come my Girl, answer before this man of God. Wilt thou be my Lawful Wife?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: As Lawsul as that Gentleman can make me.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: God a mercy: Come, Sir, to work, to work.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Indeed, and that's not very Lawful, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What a Pox ails the Fellow? Why, what Sir, 'tis not against the Law, for an Old Man to marry a young Woman, is it?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: No, Sir, but sure 'tis to Marry your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: He's mad: My Daughter, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Yes, if that Gentleman's your Son.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Good faith, Sir, even so.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I'll hang you, i'll drown you, i'll murder you, i'll poyson you, i'll blow you up, i'll bury you alive; i'll Cuckold you, you Dog.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: I'll hold you a Guinea on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ah, you Devil.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I should have Cuckolded you, Sir William; 'tis better as 'tis, I shall love now my none dear Daddy.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Come, come, be patient, Sir William, you're happy in your Sons match, though I am curst; and though I burst must bear it.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: My Son, he's a Son of a Whore, i'll prove it, and i'll fight him.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Hark you Sir, if I am not your Son, it follows naturally you're not my Father: And gad, Sir, if you abuse my Mother, I shall—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Murder me: Very well, i'll have you hang'd.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Think better, Sir William: How could you think that I, with that disparity of years, could ever love you? I do love your Son, and in your Son love you.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Come, you're a baggage. [Shakes his Head at her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'm your Daughter, Sir William; i'll be tender of you.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: I'm your Son, and Dutiful: i'll renounce the follies of the Town; i've tasted them, and weigh them all at this. We will forsake this hole of Sin and Sea-coal, and make you merry in a better Air. Come Spouse. Your blessing, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Pox take him, he talks as if he had some Grace; he made a long Speech too without swearing, but I can't say Amen to it.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Indeed Sir William, I think you're Happy, if you knew when.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Zoons, but I've lost a Wife.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, no, Sir William, if we had been married, you'd have made no more on't.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: There's your Obligation of five hundred pound to me, and truly, I think, Wisely sav'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Five hundred pound on second thoughts is a round summ: Hum! you're a Rogue; but rise, rise, and take my blessing, since I can't help it. But pox on't, where's Tom? Has no body stole his Wife? And where are these fellows, that I may see if any thing can make me laugh?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: O Sir, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What a Pox, it was not you and your Brother Tom I saw Marry'd, was it?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Even so, faith Sir; but here comes our Fortune-Hunters:

div.stage: Enter Mr. Shamtown as a Chair-man, bringing in Mr. Littlegad in Womens Habit.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Hey day, what's here? Who's in this Chair? Another damn'd Plot.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Set down the Chair, friends; who would you speak with, ha?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: We were call'd Sir, to carry this Lady; she lives in this house.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Ha! Shou'd not I know that Face: Mr. Shamtown. Indeed, I always mistrusted your Shapes, but never yet really knew you were a Chair-man. This, I suppose, is a Plot for my Brothers Lady; pray Heaven it be not her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: So, so, more Plots here; Tom shall deal with you.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I beg you would not Murder me; and Madam, I hope you'll stand to your Note, and own me, and my love.

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: Ay, me, i'm undone, and shall be laugh'd to Death.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, who is this? Betray'd, oh Hell and the Devil; where shall I run?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Hey day; what, here and there too? Tom, you're obliged to this Gentleman, he only came to steal your Lady.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: I shan't be backward in my thanks.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: I shall be kick'd to Death.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: But, who are you? Come, unmask Lady; nay, by Heaven you must, pritty Mrs. Littlegad.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Mr. Littlegad.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Two Fools well met, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: Upon my Faith, I meant it purely for your diversion; pray Pardon me. I wou'd give a hundred Pound for a Whirlwind to remove me.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Sir, this is a base return for giving you your life; but here, call up my Footmen.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Gentlemen, do not mistake, I am a Gentleman, and since I am betray'd into your House defenceless, which was cruel of the Ladies, I beg I may be safe, when next I am in my Primitive Equipments.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: What, Sir, without a Shirt?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: No, Sir, I'll give your Brother satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Shut up the Doors: Poor Fool, he Pardons any thing he scorns, and you shall share the Graces. And Gentlemen, if you lov'd these Ladies, you cannot but stay Dinner, and after Dance at their Weddings, I am sure, Mr. Spruce.
sp.stage: Enter Mr. Spruce and Mrs. Spruce.
sp.p: Name but a Dance, and up starts Mr. Spruce.

sp.speaker: Mr. Spr.
sp.p: Mr. Wealthy, I am glad you are inlarg'd; and faith; Sir, I came only to have serv'd you.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: I must thank your Lady for that, I presume.

sp.speaker: Mr. Spr.
sp.p: Gad, she loves you dearly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: I can't deny't, indeed, Mr. Wealthy, though before my Husbands face.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: I thank you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Frank, I begin to love you already. Sirrah, you are a lucky Dog, make much of her and I forgive you: and God bless you all four.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Fairly spoken, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: We'll deserve it; but come, I have provided an Entertainment. A Dance.

lg.l: Come Gentlemen, you are the only dejected here, but bear up:
And don't too much the Accident Regret,
For two, by two, we're all but Fools well met.
WHat would our Author give, you'ld go away
Half so well pleas'd as you came here to day.
That he meant well is all he has to plead;
Faith then be kind, and let his Play succeed,
And take for once the good Will for the Deed.
He don't presume to justify his Play,
Vouch it for good, or if you lik't you may.
A humbler way for your good word he takes;
You're welcom, would 'twere better for your sakes,
Therefore to damn him were very hard;
Two Fools well met's the Play, and in a word,
Forgive him, for he owns himself the third.
HOw shall I my Rivals meet?
They are too Mighty, Rich and Great:
How can I my Celia win,
A Shepheard I, and she Divine?
Or how can such a World of Charms
Be Circled in these humble Arms?
Ah Celia, If the Man that Loves thee most
Cannot deserve thee by it, I am lost.
I am lost, I am lost, Ah Celia, &c.
Propose me Wonders for my Task,
To be thy Slave is all I ask, is all I ask, &c.
The Rich may afterwards Ropine,
They would have thee; I would be thine:
Nor scorn me that I am not great,
Since then canst with a Smile create.
Let not, Oh let not then the Man be lost,
For what a Smile can give, who loves thee most.
Let not, Oh let not then the Man be lost; &c.
MY Amarillis scorns the Man
That does her Eyes adore;
Though I immortaliz'd her Name,
And Sainted her with Power:
But now the Goddess to that height is grown,
Sh'as quite forgot 'twas I that made her One.
Sh'as quite forgot, &c.
